HEADLINE: Latest German Fad: Leasing Out the Subway 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 9 

 BODY:
With smooth-running trains, bright, well-kept stations and a blissful lack of crowds, Frankfurt's subway is a pleasant surprise for people from more teeming cities.
 For American visitors who cannot get enough of the U-Bahn subway system, Frankfurt is making a special, once-in-a-lifetime offer: lease the whole system for 99 years with an upfront payment of roughly $100 million. Frankfurt will even throw in its above-ground streetcar network. 
 This arrangement is known as cross-border leasing, and it has become the latest fad for major German cities like Frankfurt, which are in a deep financial hole because of the economic downturn, eroding tax revenues and the high cost of maintaining their plush public facilities. 
Dusseldorf, Dortmund and Essen recently raised $60 million to $80 million each by leasing their subway systems to American investors. About 150 municipalities in Europe -- including some in the Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria and France -- have offered these deals, but Germany has been the largest lessee by far.
Now, Frankfurt is angling to get into the act.
Later this summer, officials from Frankfurt's public transportation authority will embark on a road show to New York, where they will try to entice investors to lease their subway and streetcar network.
The sales pitch is simple: The tax advantages of leasing a huge fixed asset, which depreciates each year, more than offset the upfront fees paid to the city. John Hancock, Bank of America and the Wachovia Bank are among the American investors that have signed such overseas leases.
"We have to look for sources of capital outside the city," said Werner Lutz, the managing director of Stadtwerke Frankfurt am Main, a holding company that oversees the city's stakes in its airport, public transit system and utilities. "We need more capital to be ready for competition."
That sounds reasonable. But it does not mollify opponents of the plan, who have papered the city with signs that say, "Cross-border leasing? Nein!" They are trying to gather 41,000 signatures to force Frankfurt to hold a referendum on the matter.
The critics say turning over the subway system, used by 266,000 riders a day, to foreign investors poses too high a risk.
They ask a host of worrisome questions: What if Frankfurt cannot afford to buy back the lease in 30 years, the first buyback option in the contract? What if a natural disaster, such as a flood, were to befall the system? What if the American tax laws that permit these investments are changed?
"We fear future generations will have no control over the city's infrastructure," said Karola Stotzel, a teacher and union official who is helping to organize the campaign.
The protesters, Ms. Stotzel said, are steering clear of appeals to anti-foreign or anti-American sentiment. "We are internationalists," she said. "This kind of tax evasion isn't good for Germans or Americans."
But some believe the recent raw feelings between the United States and Germany are subtly bolstering the campaign. "If we had not had the Iraq conflict, this would have gotten much less attention," said Georg Vietor, a director at Macquarie Corporate Finance, an Australian bank that prepared a feasibility study for Frankfurt. 
Mr. Lutz admits that Frankfurters could be alarmed by the specter of an American investor taking control of the system. "There is always the fear that the foreign investor will take over our U-Bahn and turn it into the New York City subway, which would be terrible," he said. "But of course, that's not the case."
Frankfurt would still operate the subway, repair the tracks, police the stations and collect the fares. The subway trains themselves are excluded from the lease because they become obsolete too quickly.
At heart, cross-border leases are a loophole. Because they extend over 99 years, United States tax law treats them as a sale, which gives the lease holder the benefits of depreciation. As far as German authorities are concerned, however, the ownership does not change.
"German tax authorities take a clever view," said Ulrich Eder, the managing director of Due Finance, a tax advisory firm in Dusseldorf that specializes in cross-border leases. "They say that the city is receivinga cash benefit for enabling the lease holder to gain a tax benefit."
Advocates of cross-border leasing say there is no reason German cities could not lease other pieces of infrastructure, like water systems or gas and electricity networks. For all their financial problems, German cities are still viewed as having rock-solid credit.
If Frankfurt's transportation authority attracts one or more investors, it would give a percentage of the leasing fee to the lawyers and banks that broker the deal. It would then split the net proceeds, which could range from $73 million to $98 million, with the city. It would use its share to fortify the capital structure of the subway, only 8 percent of which is equity.
Finding investors should not be difficult for Frankfurt, given the recent success of Dusseldorf and other cities. The tricky part, according to people here, will be navigating the local political currents. Frankfurt's government is a balky coalition that includes all four major political parties.
And Frankfurt can draw little comfort from the Austrian city of Salzburg, which shelved plans to lease its wastewater system last spring after factions in the government objected to the plan.
Mr. Lutz said he would prefer to finance the subway system directly from municipal coffers. But with its deficit projected to rise to more than $400 million this year, Frankfurt is in no position to do that.
"We can discuss for a long time whether it is the right thing to do," Mr. Lutz said. "But it is totally legal. When I fill out my German taxes, I take whatever deductions I am allowed to take."
As for Ms. Stotzel, she worries only that it will be tough to arouse public passions on an issue as arcane as cross-border leasing. "We're very glad we don't have to campaign to save the sewage system," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Hauptwache subway station in central Frankfurt. The city wants to lease the system to Americans. (Hans-Rudolf Oeser for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For a Shaper Of Landscapes, A Cliffhanger 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: KENTFIELD, Calif. 

 BODY:
EVERY morning, Lawrence Halprin, the 87-year-old creator of evocative public places, grabs his hiking staff from the kitchen and ambles down a series of wooden steps that wend their way through a gnarled thicket of madrone and redwood trees. 
 He plunges into the swimming pool, hewn from ancient rocks imported from China, then takes a different path back. It might be the one that snakes down the base of Mount Tamalpais to the outdoor dance deck he designed for his wife of 63 years, the choreographer Anna Halprin, or the one through a grove of old-growth redwoods whose mighty wrinkled girths he knows by heart. "I like to wander around in a place like this," he said, wearing the beat-up hiking boots he wore to the White House in March to receive the National Medal of Arts from President Bush. "So, I design for it." 
 The landscape as a stage set for human drama -- the choreography of serendipity -- is at the core of what Mr. Halprin, the tribal elder of American landscape architecture, has been creating for more than 50 years. He is the guiding force behind such places as the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial in Washington; Ghirardelli Square in San Francisco; Sea Ranch, an ecologically sensitive development on the Sonoma coast; and, most recently, a landscape for the new Lucas Film campus at the Presidio in San Francisco. 
The other morning, he sat with his wife on a red picnic bench in a cloister of trees beside his home, a rustic compound he designed with his close friend, the architect William Wurster, contemplating his life's work and the impending destruction of his landscapes. In Denver, Skyline Park, designed in the 1970's as a quiet urban canyon in abstract concrete, last month became the first major Halprin work to be demolished, and other Halprin landscapes are threatened in San Francisco, Olympia, Wash., and elsewhere. Once optimistic beacons of urban rejuvenation -- "memorable, intense, passionate rather than pretty" as he once put it -- a growing number of the austere, sculptural Halprin landscapes of the 60's and 70's are suffering from neglect and abandonment and are considered by some critics to be dated modernist eyesores out of step with their cities.
"My immediate reaction is anger," he said, his voice slightly wavery. "Then it's 'gee whiz.' We were like scouts in war, working on point to induce people to move back to the city."
The transformative power of landscape is central to both Mr. Halprin's work and the home he and Anna Halprin, an avant-garde choreographer, have created together at the end of a dead-end road. It is deeply personal terrain in which dance occurs daily (he often sketches her rehearsals) and trees literally become a part of her choreography.
They are both survivors: She has had cancer twice. He survived a World War II kamikaze attack in which his ship was split in two, killing 24 and wounding 44. He was sent to San Francisco on survivor's leave.
Their fortuitous arrival in this deeply sensuous place helped foster a naturalistic approach to landscape and dance.
He: "It encouraged my intuition. A waterfall is not intellectual."
She: "The thing that is so nice about a waterfall is it is out of control. It's spontaneous."
In a kaleidoscopic career that has embraced parks, highways, shopping centers, plazas, monuments and national parks, Mr. Halprin infused once-abandoned corners of American cities with nature's joyful spontaneity. Many of his creations were built on the fringy front lines of urban renewal. Among them are Seattle Freeway Park (1970), which reknit a neighborhood divided by an interstate with a park literally built over the freeway, and the Water Garden, soon to be demolished, at the state capitol in Olympia (1972), nestled atop a parking garage that is now in danger of collapsing.
"Larry was working at a time when no one believed in public spaces," noted the landscape architect Laurie Olin, whose firm transformed Bryant Park in Manhattan and who is now in the delicate position of replacing a Halprin sculpture garden at the Virginia Museum of Art. "No one did it with such bravura and a sense of generosity."
Today at the corporate Levi's Plaza in San Francisco (1978), gulls perch on craggy rock formations, and stepping stones invite grown-ups to climb waterfalls. Streams in granite channels meander through shaded rises, creating a gemlike eddy in the urban torrent where people whisper sweet nothings into their cellphones.
The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial (1997) in Washington is a sequence of four outdoor rooms and gardens animated by water, stone and sculpture, including bas reliefs by Robert Graham. It is landscape as powerful emotional narrative, in which Roosevelt's story unfolds like a voyage.
In conceiving new places, Mr. Halprin draws upon the essence of the places he loves, especially the High Sierras, where he has long spent summers, sketchbooks in hand. "There is a big difference between talking about nature as a romantic thing and nature as a powerful generative force," he explained, a Yoda in the redwoods with a turquoise turtle bolo. "Up there you can see the process of change, how an avalanche sounds when it's tumbling down and what happens on its way, listening to waterfalls on granite rocks. What I really love up there is how things happen. This is what I try to do when I design."
Mr. Halprin helped take landscape architecture out from behind the polite picket fence of gardening into the broader and more contentious realm of urban planning. His plazas were designed to be free-spirited spaces brimming with young people and activity. The forlorn sunken fountain at United Nations Plaza in San Francisco, for instance, now 27 years old, was conceived as "a place to walk to, sit down, do theater in."
But today, many of these abstract modernist "hardscapes" are unappreciated. Many have suffered from neglect and lack of maintenance. "Open space creates a kind of vacuum for many people," Mr. Halprin observed. "If the pumps go south and aren't repaired, the fountain goes and the place begins to seem lonely and unattractive. So they become vulnerable."
Modernist landscapes also do not fit the stereotype of a park. Charles A. Birnbaum, founder of the nonprofit Cultural Landscape Foundation, notes that Beaux Arts landscapes like Central Park are "places that people have longstanding relationships with, where picnics, weddings and concerts were held." In contrast, he said, "modernist works haven't been around long enough to endear them to people." 
United Nations Plaza recently received a reprieve from demolition by the city's Board of Supervisors, which did not view an alternative scheme as an improvement. Poised between City Hall and the Tenderloin district, it has never been universally admired. Allan Temko, former architecture critic of The San Francisco Chronicle, called it "pretentious schmaltz." Meant to mimic the Bay's tidal rhythms, the fountain is now ringed by yellow chains to prevent homeless people from bathing in it (and worse).
The protracted saga of Skyline Park in Denver pitted downtown business interests against Historic Denver, the National Trust for Historic Preservation and other cultural advocacy groups. The park, surrounded by a five-foot berm and situated below grade, was intended to be a place of downtown quiet, "a canyon-like mountain refuge in the midst of car hell," in the words of Susan Barnes-Gelt, Denver city councilwoman at large. But, as in San Francisco, it eventually drew the kind of users who relished its hidden sightlines.
Eventually the city brought in Thomas Balsley, a New York landscape architect, to reconfigure and largely demolish it.
John Desmond, director of the Downtown Denver Partnership, representing 350 property owners, campaigned for its demolition. He calls the design "dictatorial." 
"Most people didn't read it as a traditional park, and are put off by concrete, especially angular concrete," he said. "It was more sculpture than park."
The park was never loved, Ms. Barnes-Gelt said. "Denverites do not warm up to modernism," she said. "We don't really get the built environment, and we for sure don't get it if it's not red brick and at least 75 years old. Against that, Halprin's esthetic was not respected or frankly, enjoyed."
Preservationists face some tough choices as postwar landscapes age. "Famous people do great work, not-so-great work and terrible work," Mr. Olin said. "Not everything is equal." The options do not necessarily have to be either/or, he said. At Bryant Park, for instance, Mr. Olin rejected a slavish adherence to the historic design in favor of a reinterpretation. Mr. Halprin himself does not view his designs as static; in a number of cases, they could be modified, he said, to increase pedestrian traffic. "We could do lively things," he observed. "In each case there is a different solution."
The threat to Halprin works notwithstanding, there are signs of spirited reappreciation: in Portland, Ore., the Lawrence Halprin Landscapes Conservancy was recently formed to spruce up and protect Lovejoy Plaza, Ira Keller Fountain and Pettygrove Park, an ensemble considered to be one of Mr. Halprin's masterpieces.
"They're enormously powerful places," said John Russell, a developer who has pledged $100,000 to maintain the parks. "They evoke a naturalness, yet are clearly manmade."
The naturalness reflects both Mr. Halprin's connection to northern California, where his own house defers to the trees, and experiential workshops that he and his wife developed to mine group creativity -- and which he still uses to help people articulate the essence of places. They are one couple who did not miss the '60s: for a fleeting moment Dennis Hopper was married to their eldest daughter Daria (now a therapist, she starred in "Zabriskie Point").
It was Anna, whom Mr. Halprin met at the University of Wisconsin in 1939, who encouraged a weekend trip to Taliesin East, a studio of Frank Lloyd Wright's. It changed his life. In Wright's studio he recognized his calling, switching from plant science to "environments human beings occupy."
He received a scholarship to the Harvard Graduate School of Design, newly reconstituted under Walter Gropius, director of the Bauhaus. His classmates included I. M. Pei, Paul Rudolph and Philip Johnson.
The Halprins' house is a biography of their passions, filled with antique Judaica, clay figures by Mr. Graham and photos of Anna by Harold Halterstadt, a student of the Bauhaus photographer Laszlo Moholy-Nagy. A man of intense, free-wheeling enthusiasms, Mr. Halprin can become as excited about a pair of mechanical singing hamsters -- he conducts them with Maazel-like zeal -- as he can about an ancient pottery shard from the Dead Sea. 
He continues to be a force of nature in blue jeans. Working with the Yosemite Fund, he recently redesigned the approach to Yosemite Falls so that visitors are greeted by trails, not by a restroom and a parking lot. He is restoring the spiritual nature of a place that had become secular. His clients include the director George Lucas, whose new campus at the Presidio will open new vistas of the Golden Gate Bridge. "My own tastes range from Oriental to ornate and overgrown Victorian, which I'm sometimes tempted to combine," Mr. Lucas said in a phone interview. "Larry's tastes aren't quite as wide-ranging."
The other day, Mr. Halprin wandered down to the dance deck, passing an outcropping of azaleas. He looked out over the redwoods to Mount Tamalpais, its silhouette and hue constantly changing with the sky. The deck, he explained, was an improvised shape, because his wife was the kind of dancer who shouldn't be confined by a rectangle. It was design as metaphor for its creator, reaching out in all directions.

HEADLINE: Cruise Control May Be Goal of Honda's Chief 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON with MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 9 

 BODY:
A couple of years ago, the Honda Motor Company invited a few professional race-car drivers to its famed three-ringed test track in Motegi, two hours north of Tokyo, to show off its latest creations and get feedback from people who make their living through speed.
 To add to the fun that day, Honda rolled out its Side-by-Side, a Formula-One-style car with a 750-cc motorcycle engine in a slim racing body. The professionals raced the cars around the one-kilometer track in about 31 seconds. 
 Hot on their trail, however, was Takeo Fukui, then the chief of Honda's motor sports division. He circled the loop in 32 seconds. 
Mr. Fukui's competitive streak has not diminished in the years since. In fact, it has propelled Mr. Fukui, a 58-year old engineer, to the posts of president and chief executive of Honda, one of the world's most profitable automakers.
Little known outside the company, Mr. Fukui, who took charge last month, will need to channel his energy into maintaining the successes his predecessor, Hiroyuki Yoshino, achieved during the past half-decade. 
Under Mr. Yoshino's leadership, Honda expanded its factories in the United States, pushed into China and posted record profits in three of the last five years, including 427 billion yen ($3.6 billion) in 2002 alone. Defying the conventional wisdom during his tenure that global consolidation would force Honda to seek a partner, Mr. Yoshino preserved the company's independence.
Mr. Fukui vows to do the same. "I completely agree with Yoshino's strategy," he said in an interview today at Honda's headquarters here. "We might lose 90 percent of our flexibility if we teamed up with a partner."
It is not hard to find arguments for leaving well enough alone at Honda, especially when it comes to the brutally competitive American market, where carmakers fight hard for every 10th of a percentage point in market share. 
Honda has had extraordinary success in the United States in the first half of the year, gaining 1.1 percentage points in share, in large part because of new sport utility models like the relatively sedate Pilot and the quirky Element, which resembles a Brink's truck.
In Japan, Honda still ranks second behind Toyota, though its compact Honda Fit has unseated the Toyota Corolla as Japan's top-selling model. Closing the gap behind Honda has been the revitalized Nissan Motor.
According to some estimates, Honda is also the most profitable car company in China, which is considered the next big battleground for the world's auto companies. The country had been a priority for Mr. Yoshino, who was born there.
But analysts agree that Mr. Fukui's primary focus must be North America, where Honda sells 53 percent of its vehicles and generates 90 percent of its profits. The Accord and Civic sedans are selling well in the United States, with only minimal incentive marketing compared with its Detroit rivals, and the Odyssey minivan remains popular.
"Demand for our cars in the U.S. continues to be stronger than our supply," Mr. Fukui said today. "We have no target for our market share in the U.S., but our sales are on schedule."
He knows the territory. After a series of assignments in Honda's racing and research and development operations, including a job developing the engine for the original Honda CVCC minicar, Mr. Fukui was assigned in the mid-1990's to Honda's manufacturing operations in the United States.
He served as executive vice president, and then president, the job previously held by Mr. Yoshino. 
John Adams, senior vice president and general manager of manufacturing at Honda's factory in Marysville, Ohio, learned that Mr. Fukui's quiet exterior hid a streak of determination. When profits were stretched thin by the rising yen, Mr. Fukui found ways to expand substantially production at Honda's plants in Marysville, where the Accord is built, and in East Liberty, Ohio, where Civics are assembled, without spending heavily.
"It was all done with very little investment," Mr. Adams said. 
To mix better with the unit's 14,000 American employees, he adopted an Anglicized nickname, Take, which was stitched on his white plant uniform. But few Americans dared to call him that, Mr. Adams recalled in an interview. Still, Mr. Adams said, "it's very comforting for us to know someone who worked in the United States is nowpresident of the company."
An important question now being discussed throughout the American operations is whether Mr. Fukui will authorize a full-size pickup truck, the only market segment in which Honda does not compete. Mr. Fukui said Honda had no plans to develop a pickup, a project that would require a large investment, both in money and in engineering resources, and take the company into unfamiliar technical territory.
Joseph Phillippi of Auto Trends Consulting in Short Hills, N.J., said, "They just don't have the engineering history and background to do a full-size pickup truck." He added, "They're so focused on adding lightness and fuel economy."
Mr. Phillippi and other analysts said that Honda would do better to revitalize its Acura luxury division. Although Acura reached the United States in the mid-1980's, ahead of the Lexus from Toyota and the Infiniti from Nissan, Honda has been overshadowed by them in consumers' minds despite occasional hits like the MDX luxury sport utility vehicle.
Acura posted a 3.4 percent sales gain in June, but for the first half of the year as a whole, sales were down 5.2 percent. "Honda doesn't have any good experience nurturing a premium brand," said Kunihiko Shiohara, who follows Honda for Goldman, Sachs in Japan. "Their consumer image is not luxury, but value for money." 
Mr. Fukui acknowledged that the Acura could use some attention. "So far, it has been a successful business, but we need to strengthen our brand by adding new products," he said.
Whichever task he focuses on first, Mr. Fukui is unlikely to try to transform Honda with the ferocity that Carlos Ghosn has applied to Nissan. Mr. Ghosn has become a household name in Japan for the swift financial turnaround he engineered at Nissan and for its phalanx of hot-selling vehicles. 
Mr. Fukui's low-key approach is much in keeping with the general atmosphere at Honda. Unusual for a car company, Honda has its top executives sit in one large room, not separate offices. They can convene meetings simply by swiveling their chairs.
Working in such close contact means that the executive team tends to make decisions jointly, suggesting that whatever changes are made under Mr. Fukui's leadership are likely to be incremental rather than drastic, analysts said. 
Though he may focus on the United States, Mr. Fukui will have to be mindful of Honda's position in Japan, which has been mired in an economic slump for nearly a decade. 
High labor and distribution costs and buyers' preference for smaller cars, prompted by the high price of fuel, have meant that, at best, Honda breaks even on its car sales in Japan, analysts said. But Japan is where the company's all-important research-and-development centers are based.
Efforts to correct this geographic imbalance have met with mixed results. Honda fell short of Mr. Yoshino's goal of selling one million cars a year at home, and its domestic sales fell by 20.3 percent in the first half of the year. 
"Honda is consolidating their position in Japan and using Japan as an R&D base, which is fine, because no one makes money here," said Kurt Sanger, an auto analyst at ING Securities in Tokyo. "In reality, everyone is reliant on overseas sales, because that is where the money is made."
The challenges before him make it unlikely that Mr. Fukui will have much time for his favorite pastime, golf. He lamented today that his handicap had increased 2 strokes, to 10, since he returned to Japan from Ohio.
That is further evidence of his competitive streak, said Koichi Amemiya, a Honda executive vice president who oversees North American operations. "He's quiet on the outside, but there's no doubt that he has a fire on the inside," Mr. Amemiya said.

HEADLINE: ARTS BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  By Lawrence Van Gelder 

 BODY:
 HIGHLIGHTS

FRANCE: ARTS DISPUTE UPDATE -- Total collapse threatened the summer arts festival season in France yesterday as performers and technicians intensified walkouts and protests in a dispute over efforts to reduce their unemployment benefits, news agencies reported. The weeklong Francofolies festival of music and song, scheduled to start tomorrow in La Rochelle, an Atlantic port, was called off a day after the cancellation of the opening of the Avignon theater festival in the south. In Paris, some 650 demonstrators stormed a Seine River bridge, shutting down filming of an untitled romantic comedy directed by Nancy Meyers and starring Keanu Reeves, Jack Nicholson and Diane Keaton. The first week of an outdoor film festival in Paris was also called off, and on Tuesday, performances in the city's two opera houses were canceled. Festivals in the towns of Pau, Rennes, Albi and Montlucon have also been called off as a result of the dispute.

GERMANY: POTTERMANIA -- Although the newly published "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix" has become the first English-language book to lead the German best-seller list, readers impatient for the arrival on Nov. 8 of the German-language version are busily translating the 870-page novel on the Web. Contributors are asked to translate a couple of pages into German. In return, they receive access to the work of other translators of the book. So far, 3,000 pages appear on the site, because some have been duplicated. "The translations have been varied," Bernd Koelman, the operator of the site, told Reuters. "Some are great at catching the British irony; others are very strict translations, and some have tried to adapt the English into regional dialects, such as the Berlin dialect." He added: "What this shows is that contrary to expectations, young people like translating, and they can take pride in it. They can't do it at school, but they are doing it here of their own free will." The newspaper Bild said: "Our children are becoming language geniuses of their own free will, thanks to the book. Only magic is faster than this."

ENGLAND: POTTER REAL ESTATE -- Harry Potter's house is up for sale. To fans, the address is No. 4 Privet Drive, where the orphaned Harry was living with those detestable Muggles, the Dursleys, when first encountered in the J. K. Rowling saga about the boy wizard. In reality, the house stands at No. 12 Picket Post Close in Bracknell, in southeast England. It was chosen for the Dursleys' home by Warner Brothers for the 2001 film "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" because it lacked interesting features, according to British newspapers. With an estimated price of $415,000, the house is to be auctioned on July 22 in London, Reuters reported yesterday.

DANCE: TAKING FLIGHT -- Doug Varone choreographed "The Beating of Wings." Dwight Rhoden called his dance "Sky Garden." Bebe Miller choreographed "Aerodigm," and Bill T. Jones, "and before." For Jawole Zollar, it was "Eurydice's Flight." These five works were commissioned by the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the first flight by the Wright brothers, natives of Dayton, Ohio. Kevin Ward, the artistic director of the company, says: "What better way to celebrate the triumph and dreams of flight than through the art of dance and with D.C.D.C?" At 8 p.m. Saturday and 4 p.m. Sunday, in two programs at the Victoria Theater in Dayton, the company will present "The Flight Project" before embarking on tours that will take it to 20 places between September and May. From Dec. 9 through 13, "The Flight Project" will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the Next Wave Festival.

MUSIC: BOTSTEIN IN JERUSALEM -- Leon Botstein (below right), the president of Bard College, the music director and principal conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra and the founder and co-artistic director of the Bard Music Festival, has accepted an invitation to become the music director of the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Botstein's tenure begins with the 2003-04 season and will include concerts planned and conducted by him, as well as by the ensemble's principal guest conductor, Gabor Hollerung, and its resident conductor, Dan Ettinger. The orchestra has been without a music director since 2000, when David Shalon resigned shortly before his death.

FOOTNOTES

Once upon a time there were 15 men named Frank. Along with a fellow named Pekka, they set out across Helsinki, Finland, in search of the open spaces of Eira, a suburb across the river, dying and disappearing one by one along the way. So goes "Calamari Union." At 4:30 p.m. today, at BAM Rose cinemas, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, this deadpan 1985 comedy opens a 14-day retrospective devoted to the Finnish filmmaker Aki Kaurismaki (above). "Kaurismaki Goes America" includes many of his features and short works. Included are "Crime and Punishment" (1983), which sets Dostoyevsky's novel in modern Helsinki; the cult favorite "Leningrad Cowboys Go America" (1989), about a touring rock band, and "I Hired a Contract Killer" (1990), starring Truffaut's leading man Jean-Pierre Leaud as a suicidal clerk who hires a hit man to kill him but can't find him after meeting a girl who might make him change his mind. This BAMcinematek presentation continues through July 27.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Drug Costs Are Soaring for Elderly 

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
As Congress tries to come up with a bill providing a Medicare drug benefit that it can send to President Bush, a new study says prices for the 50 drugs most prescribed for the elderly rose last year at more than three times the rate of inflation. 
 The study, which was issued yesterday by Families USA, a consumer group, shows "how important it is to offer significant subsidies to the lowest-income seniors," Ron Pollack, the group's executive director, said in a telephone interview. 
 As many as half of the elderly do not have insurance for drugs for some part of the year, he said, because they either lack coverage or have exceeded the limits on their policies, which frequently cap the amount the insurer must pay. 
Prices for the 50 drugs increased an average of 6 percent, compared with a rise of 1.8 percent in the Consumer Price Index, excluding energy prices, the study said. More than half of the drugs increased by three or more times the inflation rate, while a quarter stayed the same. 
Over the years, drug prices have consistently outpaced inflation, said Mr. Pollack, who noted that these increases are particularly hard on the elderly, who are often on fixed incomes. 
An elderly person without coverage buying Lipitor, Vioxx, Synthroid and Fosamax would pay nearly $3,000 a year for all four drugs, Families USA said. 
The study met with sharp criticism from the pharmaceutical industry, which argued that many elderly people were able to buy drugs at discounted prices. "Regrettably, Families USA has decided to continue complaining about prescription medicines, rather than to pitch in and help seniors get the medicines they need," the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, a trade association, said in a statement. "Instead of misleading seniors by referencing only undiscounted prices, it should be helping them gain access to the life-saving, cost-effective medicines they need." 
Many drug companies also offer programs that help seniors get free or discounted drugs, the association said. 
Claritin, the popular allergy drug made by Schering-Plough, was among the drugs that have gone up in price the most in the last year, the study said, with its price rising nearly 12 times the rate of inflation. 
The drug, which is now available without a prescription, has since fallen steeply in price and could fall further as more generic manufacturers offer cheaper versions.
While Schering-Plough would not comment on its pricing for individual drugs, a spokesman said the company was committed to offering free or discounted medicine to help people who could not afford its drugs. 
With Congress now trying to reach a compromise between the Senate and House bills, some proponents of the Senate version, which calls for more aid to low-income elderly people, used yesterday's study to bolster their position. Under the Senate bill, a low-income person would pay $74 out-of-pocket for those four drugs, compared with $1,084 under the House bill, according to Families USA.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who was among the Senate Democrats who recently sent a letter to President Bush calling for certain provisions in the final legislation, cited the report in a statement yesterday. Medicare beneficiaries "need a bill that provides prescription drug coverage for all seniors, but with extra help for lower income retirees, with low premiums and low co-payments," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Slip on Profit Taking Ahead of Earnings Reports

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street pulled back yesterday as investors cashed in profits from the market's recent rally while they awaited second-quarter earnings reports.
 Fears of a potentially unfavorable legal ruling against the Altria Group also weighed on shares. 
 "It's an earnings game from here on out," said Mike Kayes, chief investment officer at Eastover Capital in Charlotte, N.C. "We'll be in for some choppy days until we have a clear direction on what earnings might look like."
The Dow Jones industrial average declined 66.88 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,156.21, after a two-day gain of 152 points. 
The broader market finished mixed. The Nasdaq composite index inched up 1 point, or 0.1 percent, to 1,747.46, having advanced 84 points so far this week to reach its highest level in nearly 15 months.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 5.63 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,002.21, after a two-day gain of 22 points.
The Altria Group, a component of the Dow and the parent of Philip Morris, declined $2.77, or 5.9 percent, to $44, on speculation that an Illinois appellate court might overturn a lower court's decision to reduce the bond needed to appeal a $10.1 billion tobacco verdict. 
A government report showing an unexpected drop in wholesale inventories also pressured stocks. The Commerce Department reported that inventories declined 0.3 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted level of $289.34 billion. Economists had predicted a smaller rise.
While stocks have rallied in recent months, investors are now looking to second-quarter earnings for more solid proof that the economy is rebounding.
Analysts said an absence of significant positive news also prompted many investors to sell, unlike Tuesday's string of merger announcements, which helped the Dow to close modestly higher.
"The biggest question is whether technology will continue to lead and earnings will accelerate," Mr. Kayes said. "Investors are holding their breath until that occurs," he said. "Investors are wondering, 'Do we jump into tech stocks now, given the big advance, or sell them if earnings don't go through?' "
Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee, agreed. "The general feeling is that a lot of things are in place to get the market going -- interest rates are low," for one, and there is also a tax cut package, he said. "The market in general is digesting the big run-up that we've had, looking at second-quarter earnings and waiting for the next big, significant news."
Tenet Healthcare slipped 5 cents, to $12.10, after it said it had received a civil subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission indicating a formal investigation; the S.E.C. had been informally reviewing the company's Medicare charges at its hospitals since November.
Alcoa, another Dow component, fell 34 cents, to $25.47, although it reported second-quarter earnings that beat analysts' estimates by 3 cents a share; Morgan Stanley cut the company's stock rating to equal-weight from overweight.
Gainers included Citigroup, which rose 62 cents, to $45.99, after Prudential raised the bank's stock rating to hold from sell.

By Bloomberg News
Treasury prices rose yesterday on speculation that forecasts for economic growth in the second half of the year may be overstated.
The 10-year Treasury note increased 9/32, to a price of 99 16/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, declined to 3.68 percent from 3.72 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 110 14/32. The bond's yield fell to 4.70 percent from 4.72 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Canada to Offer Marijuana to Medical Patients 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 9 

 BODY:
The Canadian government announced an interim plan today that will provide marijuana on a regular basis to several hundred people who are authorized to use the drug for medical reasons.
 Coming six weeks after the federal government introduced a bill decriminalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana and only days after it approved a trial "safe injection site" in Vancouver for intravenous drug users, the marijuana plan was one more sign that Ottawa is moving in a very different direction on drug policy from the Bush administration. 
 Thousands of Canadians already visit so-called "compassion clubs" in Vancouver and a few other cities, which distribute marijuana to those who come with a note from a doctor saying that the drug can help their condition. The police have occasionally entered some of the clinics and seized marijuana, but for the most part they function in the open. 
The decision to allow the government to provide marijuana to people with illnesses ranging from cancer to arthritis to epilepsy was forced by a ruling in January by the Ontario Superior Court that federal marijuana access regulations were unconstitutional because they did not provide patients with a legal distribution system.
The government is appealing the ruling, meaning that the announcement may not stand.
"It was never our intention to sell the product," said Health Minister Anne McClellan, a skeptic of medical marijuana use.
The cabinet is divided on whether the government should be growing and distributing marijuana, an activity that is otherwise illegal. Ms. McClellan noted today that there is a lack of clinical evidence that marijuana has medicinal benefits. She added that the government will conduct its own clinical trials, scheduled to begin this fall, to gauge possible benefits.
The government says it intends to distribute the marijuana through doctors. Some officials of doctors associations have raised cautions about doing so before there is more study about the impact of marijuana use on people's health.
While the courts decide on the government's appeal, Ottawa will provide as many as 500 people, who have received letters from doctors saying the drug offered them medical benefits, with dried marijuana and marijuana seeds for their own planting. 
The marijuana will cost patients almost $4 a gram, or about half the black market price.
The bags of seeds will cost about $15. The marijuana will come from an underground laboratory situated in an old mine in Flin Flon, Manitoba.
"This is a very small victory but a victory nevertheless," said Alison Myrden, a multiple sclerosis patient who appeared before television cameras today in front of the Parliament building holding a marijuana plant and smoking a marijuana cigarette.

HEADLINE: High Official Quits Treasury And Woman Is Named No. 2 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER with MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
The Bush administration announced changes in its economic team yesterday, including the appointment of the first woman to be deputy Treasury secretary and the resignation of Peter R. Fisher as under secretary for domestic finance.
 The new deputy Treasury secretary, assuming her nomination is confirmed by the Senate, will be Susan C. Schwab, now dean of the University of Maryland School of Public Affairs. She is experienced in international trade and was an assistant secretary of commerce in the first Bush administration and would fill the No. 2 job at Treasury, which has been vacant since the end of February. 
 A senior Bush administration official said Ms. Schwab was the choice of the White House, which had made clear it wanted a woman for the job. 
Traditionally the deputy secretary oversees all operations in the department, freeing the secretary to focus on policy and serving as an economic spokesman for the administration.
Mr. Fisher will be succeeded by Kenneth Leet, an investment banker from Goldman Sachs, adding another Goldman alumnus to the administration. Stephen Friedman, a former co-chairman at Goldman, is now chairman of the National Economic Council.
Despite the craving of many traders in the Treasury market, Mr. Fisher's departure may not open the door for the return of the 30-year Treasury bond, some traders and analysts say. In a surprise move in October 2001, Mr. Fisher eliminated the 30-year bond from the regular auction of securities. Ever since then, even as the federal budget swung from surpluses back to near-record deficits, Mr. Fisher has insisted there is no need to resume sales of this bond, once a popular benchmark for the fixed-income market.
It is possible, however, that Mr. Fisher, who worked at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York before moving to the Treasury, could become a candidate again for the job as president of the bank. He withdrew his name as a candidate in May. But since then the search committee has been unable to find a new president, and the bank named Jamie B. Stewart, the first vice president, as interim president. Mr. Fisher was not available for comment on this or other issues, a Treasury spokeswoman said.
During Mr. Fisher's tenure at the Treasury he oversaw the reopening of the bond market after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a surprise sale of 10-year Treasury notes to ease market distortions after the attacks, and broad changes in Treasury operations. These changes included the buyback of existing debt with money from the budget surplus, increased borrowing, and issuing of new securities needed to cover a deficit now projected to exceed $400 billion this fiscal year.
He was at the center of other important policy decisions as a member of both the agency that insures pensions and the Air Transportation Stabilization Board.
In his resignation letter to the president, Mr. Fisher said, "I have come to the conclusion that it will be best for my family to return to New Jersey." To allow for a transition, his resignation is effective Oct. 10.
Mr. Leet, who joined Goldman Sachs in 1986, runs the industrials group of the investment banking division in Europe and is a partner. He met Treasury Secretary John W. Snow in 1999 when he worked with CSX on the sale of Sealand Services to A. P. Moller-Maersk and has kept up the relationship since then, a Goldman spokesman said. His new job also requires Senate confirmation.
"The Bush administration seems to have learned that the key to good economic policy making is just stockpile as many Goldman partners as you can," said Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson ICAP, a research firm.
James Capra, president of Capra Asset Management in Rye, N.Y., and a member of the outside committee that consults with the Treasury on its debt policies, said that he did not expect Mr. Fisher's departure to lead to the revival of the 30-year bond soon. He said that the staff that works with Mr. Fisher is also opposed to the bond's revival. In addition, he said, the Treasury is working on a study that argues that the 30-year bond is not an efficient way to raise money for the government because it is more expensive, in terms of interest cost, than shorter-term maturities, like the 10-year note.
Mr. Fisher had substantial influence over pension policy at a time when many of America's pension funds were deteriorating sharply and corporate sponsors were lobbying for relief. The Treasury secretary is an ex-officio director of the agency that insures pensions, and Mr. Snow designated Mr. Fisher to represent him at agency meetings.
As adverse market conditions ate away at the solvency of pension plans, many companies found that they had to make large pension contributions to keep their plans compliant with federal rules. Before long, business groups began to attack the rules, saying they were irrational and needed to be relaxed. 
Some also blamed Mr. Fisher directly for their pension difficulties, because of his decision to suspend issuance of the 30-year bond. Since 1987, companies have been required to use the 30-year Treasury rate as a factor in their pension calculations. Lobbyists for the business community argued that by suspending the bond, Mr. Fisher distorted the values of corporate pension funds, making it harder than ever to keep the plans properly funded.
Mr. Fisher did not just resist the pressure to relax the pension rules, however. He also pushed forcefully for an entirely new way of measuring pension values -- one that would have the effect of tightening the pension rules, particularly for the companies with the sickest plans.
Mr. Fisher was one of three voting members on the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which Congress set up after the Sept. 11 attacks to dole out up to $15 billion in aid and loan guarantees to the troubled airline industry.
In general, Mr. Fisher voted against helping applicants. His reluctance reflected the views of Paul H. O'Neill, the former Treasury secretary, who had expressed reservations about the mission of the board. For example, while his two peers on the board voted in December 2001 to give America West a $380 million loan guarantee, Mr. Fisher opposed it.
Last December, Mr. Fisher voted against giving United Airlines a $1.8 billion loan guarantee, helping to push the company, the world's second-largest airline, into bankruptcy court. On the afternoon of Dec. 4, after the board announced its decision, Mr. Fisher gave a terse explanation for his vote. "This is not just about costs," he said, "it's about a business plan that is fundamentally flawed."

PERSON: James A. Garner 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
This Black Mayor Is Proud of His Republican Roots

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. 

 BODY:
"I DON'T get headaches; I give them," James A. Garner says bluntly on a recent afternoon here, cruising his black Crown Victoria through his beloved Long Island village. He is showing it off.
 The comment is matter of fact and funny, a response to a double-barreled query about being a Republican mayor in a Democratic village and how he feels about detractors who view him, an urban black mayor, as a toady to be trotted out by the Republican Party. 
 Mr. Garner, who makes it clear he takes no guff, says "I demand respect and I get it." 
The mayor is a towering presence at 6 foot 5, with a balding crown of white hair. His manner is plain-spoken and confident. And at age 58, he remains one popular guy. This is his fourth term as Republican mayor in a village of 56,000 in which Democrats outnumber Republicans three to one. 
Call it Garnerville. He has held the post since 1989. He was the first black elected mayor on Long Island. 
Mr. Garner's platform rose higher last month when he was elected president of the United States Conference of Mayors, the first black Republican to win the post. He says he will promote sustainable development, and sees mayors as "public C.E.O.'s." 
O.K. Let's get to the nitty-gritty. Mr. Garner says flatly that he intends to milk the new platform. "I want to use my clout to get more federal dollars here," he says. "I'm obviously trying to bring more attention to my town." On this day, Mr. Garner is leaning his big frame over the steering wheel, promising to give a tour that reveals the real village, warts and all. At the moment, he is looking at its rattier fringes. 
"See all this mess in here?," he says, motioning to a stretch of auto repair shops and shabby buildings headed for urban renewal. "I'm going to clean it all up. We're going to get all this mess out of the way." But Mr. Garner really wants to show off the good stuff. He heads toward the two shopping centers. He is explaining how Hempstead is on an upswing after decades of decline. He drives past the new $22 million Long Island Rail Road station, next to the bus terminal. He points to the big retailers: Home Depot, Old Navy and Staples. Over there, he says proudly, is the Chuck E. Cheese. "I mean this is absolutely fabulous!" He notes that Costco and Lowe's are on their way.
"You ask me how I was able to get elected with three-to-one Democrats, and that's the story," he says. "The people who elected me say, 'Mr. Mayor, I don't care who you are. All I know is that Hempstead was going down the tubes and I could care less what you are in terms of party registration. All I know is that you brought home the bacon.' This town is flourishing."
Mr. Garner has gotten elected on the independent Unity Party line, which embraces various political factions in the predominantly black and Latino village. He says his constituents do not see him as a truly hard-line Republican. Even so, he is proud of his Republican roots, and he can go on and on! He says he has visited the White House about 10 times since George W. Bush got elected. "I love him. I really do." Mr. Garner is working to get Tom Ridge, the homeland security chief, to brief a group of mayors when they visit Hempstead later this month. "My fingers are crossed."
Before Mr. Garner became mayor, he was a village board trustee. But he's a businessman at heart. The son of sharecroppers from North Carolina, in 1976 he started an exterminating company out of the basement of his home. The company is now run by his son. His daughter is a health care administrator. In 1990, during his first mayoral term, Mr. Garner earned a bachelor's degree after studying business management and communications at Adelphi University.
He has been divorced for three years, but one senses he does not want to talk about this. He says he and his ex-wife have an amicable relationship. Is he seeing anyone? "Not really," he says, seeming a bit uncomfortable. 
So does he have political aspirations? A village Republican Party leader has said that Mr. Garner has potential in a future Congressional race. 
Asked about this, Mr. Garner is coy. He chuckles. "I'm just trying to build up history now," he says. "Everybody's got political aspirations. The bottom line is lawyers want to become judges. Preachers want to be bishops."
AND? "I'm not ruling it out," he replies. "I got aspirations. Yeah, I do."
But for now, Mr. Garner has aspirations for Hempstead. He wants the village to be legally converted to a city so that it can collect its local share of sales tax. He drives down a street lined with national auto dealerships. "Little Detroit," he calls it. "Look! It's all automobiles and if I could get some sales tax out of this, I could lower people's property tax, possibly. If we can collect some sales tax, oh my God, we'll be on our way." 
Garnerville. It has a ring to it. What does he think? He smiles widely. "You can call it whatever you want, as long as we get some sales tax out of it." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: JAMES A. GARNER (Dan Neville for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wholesale Inventories Fell 0.3% In May, Commerce Dept. Reports 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Wholesale inventories fell 0.3 percent in May, to $289.34 billion, according to a government report released yesterday. 
 The decrease matched April's decline and reflected fewer supplies of automobiles, machinery and electrical equipment, the Commerce Department said in Washington. 
 Economists surveyed by Bloomberg News had forecast a 0.2 percent increase in wholesale inventories for May.
May wholesale sales fell 0.5 percent after dropping 2.5 percent. Relative to sales, wholesale inventories remained at 1.24 months' supply and still close to a record-low 1.21 months' worth in March. Companies have been reluctant to fill their warehouses and shelves until demand improves. 
Inventories "are at rock bottom right now," said Astrid Adolfson, a senior economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York. "Until sales are on a firm footing, and there are signs that's going to extend beyond a one-month period, we won't see any significant buildup of inventories." 
Goods on shelves and in warehouses subtracted 0.82 percent from first-quarter growth of 1.4 percent, the latest Commerce Department figures showed. In each quarter last year, stockpiles contributed to economic growth. 
Wholesale inventories account for about a fourth of all business stockpiles. Retail and factory inventories make up the rest. Wholesale inventories are tied to imports because many foreign goods, like oil and cars, are stocked by distributors before being shipped to retailers. 
Inventories of durable goods, which include computers, hardware and lumber, fell 0.3 percent in May after falling 0.2 percent in April. Durable goods sales declined 0.4 percent after falling 0.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Fees and Trustees: Paying the Keepers of the Cash 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
The Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation is known for its generosity, giving tens of millions of dollars each year to Jewish organizations like Yeshiva University and the Hebrew Home for the Aged, as well as to places like Lincoln Center.
 The foundation is also generous to its five trustees, paying each of them, including two investment bankers, $175,000 in 2001, the latest year for which data is available. 
 The fees that the Goldsmith Foundation and others like it pay their trustees have moved into the spotlight as part of a vitriolic debate over a provision in a tax bill pending in the House of Representatives that would force the institutions to spend more of their assets each year on charity.
"Why should foundation trustees be paid to do charitable work when, with few exceptions, they are among the wealthiest and most highly paid professionals in America and when millions of Americans of all economic classes are paid nothing to sit on boards of nonprofit organizations?" asks Pablo Eisenberg, a senior fellow at the Center for Study of Volunteer Organizations and Service at Georgetown University. 
All of the Goldsmith Foundation's trustees are related to Mr. Goldsmith, who died in 1980 after making a fortune on Wall Street. Two, Robert and Richard Menschel, are senior directors at Goldman, Sachs & Company who received more than $20 million in stock when the investment bank went public in 1999 and made millions in compensation before that.
Richard Menschel said that while he would work as a trustee for nothing, the fees Goldsmith paid were not excessive, given their record for increasing the assets and given that the foundation had no paid staff.
"You have to ask what is the overall cost of any other type of similar organization and what do they accomplish versus what we do, and that, I think, speaks for itself," Mr. Menschel said.
Under current law, foundations must spend at least 5 percent of their assets each year to maintain their tax-exempt status, but they may count some administrative expenses, like legal fees, rent and compensation, including trustee fees.
The pending legislation would require foundations to give the entire 5 percent to charity, forcing them to dip into other assets to pay trustees. That would increase their spending between four-tenths and eight-tenths of one percent, depending on their staffing, according to data from the Council on Foundations.
Foundation executives say the potential switch poses the biggest threat to their long-term existence since 1969, when Congress first made tax exemption contingent on their spending. They contend that raising the required "payout" would exhaust their assets, thereby violating some donors' intentions of establishing a foundation in perpetuity.
To save money, some foundation officials have said they would have to cut back on things like annual reports and other publications and auditing and oversight. 
There has been no mention, however, of cutting compensation for trustees and executives, which accounts for a bigger chunk of expenditures -- almost 16 percent of the average annual expenses foundations counted toward meeting the 5 percent target in the decade ending 1999, according to Internal Revenue Service data compiled by the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy.
Printing accounted for 2.6 percent of the expenses; accounting and legal expenses for 6.2 percent.
"I think it is a little odd for them to say they will reduce their expenditures on things like auditing and legal matters, which keep them in compliance with the law, given how minimal those expenses are in comparison with other expenses," said Rick Cohen, executive director of the committee, which has long pushed for higher foundation payouts.
Foundations executives defend the salaries they receive, saying they oversee the administration of billions of dollars. Trustees' roles are less clear, and thus the fees they receive have come under greater scrutiny.
"It's a little hard to say that under no circumstances should a foundation pay a trustee," said Peter Frumkin, an associate professor of public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard who is affiliated with the university's Hauser Center for Nonprofit Organizations. "Because in some cases trustees are doing the work of staff, although that's rare." Mr. Frumkin added, "I don't see the issue as black and white, but it's definitely shaded more toward it being better not to pay these fees than to pay them."
Foundations executives and trustees say trustees do not get enough credit for the work they do as stewards of charitable assets. They say foundation trustees seem to be more diligent about attending meetings than their corporate counterparts, and say they can spend hours reading to prepare for meetings and traveling to far-flung places to convene. 
Paul A. Allaire, the former chairman and chief executive of the Xerox Corporation who is chairman of the Ford Foundation, said Ford's trustees are asked to attend three two-day meetings a year and spend one week visiting a site or organization supported by Ford, in addition to whatever time they need to prepare. 
"I would say on average we expect our trustees to spend 15 to 20 days a year, a big portion of their lives, working on foundation activities," Mr. Allaire said in a telephone interview two weeks ago.
He received $26,850 as Ford's chairman in the year that ended Sept. 30, 2001, but said he would sit on the board for nothing. He is not paid as a board member of the New York City Ballet or Outward Bound USA.
Robert E. Campbell, who received $56,000 in 2001 as chairman of the $9 billion Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, said foundation trustees had more onerous responsibilities as stewards for charitable assets than directors of nonprofit organizations like the ballet or Outward Bound, whose primary responsibility is fund-raising. "The boards of hospitals, universities and what have you, those are places where you are giving advice and counsel, but since they are generally institutions out there raising money instead of giving out grants, you are doing something completely different," he said.
Mr. Campbell also said he would do foundation work for nothing, but Juanita M. Kreps, an economist who was secretary of commerce in the Carter administration, said she would not serve on the board of the $6 billion Duke Endowment if she were not paid to do so.
"I don't think we're being overpaid," said Ms. Kreps, who along with 14 other trustees was paid $132,799.55 plus expenses in 2001. "We do a lot of work. We meet two full days 10 times a year in Charlotte, which isn't the easiest place to get to, and there's a good bit of correspondence to deal with in between."
Trustees of the Duke Endowment have no choice in whether they are paid. When the tobacco tycoon James B. Duke established the endowment, he stipulated that 3 percent of its investment income be divided evenly among them.
His daughter, Doris Duke, set even more generous terms for trustees of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, although those were reduced as part of a settlement with the New York State attorney general.
So John J. Mack, who receives compensation valued in the tens of millions of dollars as chief executive of Credit Suisse First Boston, received $126,078 in 2001 as a trustee of Ms. Duke's foundation.
Mr. Mack refused to comment, but he is known for working long hours with no pay as a board member at two major hospitals in New York City and at other nonprofits. A spokeswoman for him said he gives the money he receives from the Duke Foundation to charity.
J. Paul Getty, the oil magnate, took a completely opposite approach, explicitly forbidding payments to trustees when he established the J. Paul Getty Trust in 1953. "The trust indenture is a remarkable document in that it has relatively few restrictions in general, but it does have that particular provision," said Peter C. Erichson, the trust's general counsel and secretary.
Toward the opposite end of the spectrum is the Goldsmith Foundation. 
New York law is vague on the issue of trustee fees, allowing "reasonable" compensation of board members, and James Slaughter, a Goldsmith trustee, said the level of compensation paid by the foundation to its trustees was approved by its legal and accounting advisers.
He noted that Mr. Goldsmith left $80 million to the foundation. Since then, it has given away more than $250 million, exceeding the 5 percent spending target every year of its existence.
"We have managed to increase the capital by more than 10 times, whereas today it is more than $800 million, so I would say the record is as good as anybody's and certainly better than most," Mr. Slaughter said.
He added, "That's all due to the trustees, who act as investment, administrative and program officers, which is different from other foundations our size that have paid staff."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about fees paid to trustees of private foundations misstated the asset value of the Duke Endowment, whose trustees divide 3 percent of its investment income. It is $2.5 billion, not $6 billion.

HEADLINE: $9.6 Billion Plan Announced for Redesign of Los Angeles Airport to Thwart Terrorists 

BYLINE:  By NICK MADIGAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 9 

 BODY:
In an effort to thwart terrorists, much of Los Angeles International Airport will be rebuilt at a cost of $9.6 billion under a plan that would ban all cars from the terminal areas.
 In effect, the plan will do away with pick-ups and drop-offs and force airline passengers to check in for their flights and board trains to their planes at a new facility a mile east of the terminals. 
 In that respect, the new plan, announced today by Mayor James K. Hahn, resembles emergency measures undertaken at the airport immediately after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on New York and the Pentagon, when the authorities here prohibited private traffic to the airfield for five weeks and moved passengers onto shuttle buses.
The plan, Mayor Hahn said, would increase the number of passengers passing through the airport each year by more than 20 million and would make the 75-year-old airport, commonly known as LAX, "the safest and most secure airport in America." It represents "new thinking in our post-9/11 environment," he said. 
During a news conference this morning, Mayor Hahn dismissed the conclusion of a RAND Corporation study that concentrating all passengers in the new check-in location, to be called the Ground Transportation Center, would actually increase the number of casualties in a terrorist attack.
One of the mayor's security consultants, John Hensley, said the plan "allows for concentric rings of security," beginning with the off-site structures.
"You have the ability to secure the inner core," Mr. Hensley said, referring to the passenger terminals.
If the Los Angeles City Council approves the plan, workers would begin construction in late 2004 and be finished around 2015. The reconstruction would be one of the largest public works projects in the United States, the mayor said, and would be paid for not by taxpayers' dollars but through a combination of bonds, grants, concession revenues, leases and increased landing fees.
The mayor's planners envisage demolishing three of the airport's nine antiquated terminals as well as all existing parking structures. A vast new passenger terminal would be built, as would a structure where rental car operations would be consolidated. The new buildings would be connected by a "people-mover" train, an amenity already in place at many other large airports.
"Modernization has escaped LAX," said Mr. Hahn, who pointed out that most of the current gates and terminals were designed in the 1960's, when the largest passenger aircraft in use was the Boeing 707. "It wasn't designed for the wingspan of a 747."
Mayor Hahn was careful to call the project a redesign of the airport and not an expansion, despite his proposal to build three large new structures. The Los Angeles airport, which currently serves about 56 million passengers a year, will serve no more than 78 million under the new plan, the mayor said, a concession to neighbors of the airport who were appalled by earlier proposals that called for handling as many as 98 million passengers a year.
Nevertheless, the plan has drawn fire from residents of adjoining communities like Playa del Rey and Westchester, who consider it an unnecessarily intrusive expansion of what is already the nation's fifth-busiest airport.
"Any time you make an improvement to an airport you open it up to expansion," said Roy Hefner, 75, who lives in Westchester one mile north of LAX's northernmost runway. "Mayor Hahn calls it a modernization -- it's a synonym for expansion."
Mr. Hefner, a retired schoolteacher who has served on the LAX Area Advisory Committee since it was founded in 1975, said it was pointless for the mayor to speak of capping the number of passengers at the airport, since only the Federal Aviation Administration has the power to address such matters.
Nevertheless, Mayor Hahn called the proposal "fair to the surrounding communities, who will have to bear with increased traffic."
The mayor acknowledged that the airport's neighbors "won't stand for it" if the growth of LAX is not kept in check. To that end, Mr. Hahn said he foresaw the evolution of the airfield in the context of a regional aviation plan calling for expansion of airports in cities well beyond Los Angeles, like Palmdale and Ontario, and the revival of a plan to turn a former El Toro Marine Corps base in Orange County into a commercial airport. Just last year, Orange County residents rejected such an airport at El Toro.
Here in Los Angeles, some people who were previously opposed to expanding LAX have been won over by Mr. Hahn's plan, which will be the subject of nine public hearings starting on Monday.
Mike Gordon, the mayor of El Segundo, south of the airport, said today that he had been mollified by assurances that his town would not suffer, despite his concern about a facet of the plan that calls for moving the southernmost runway closer to El Segundo to allow room for a new taxiway.

HEADLINE: Litigants in Housing Court Fear What State Fees Will Bring 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
Albany did not, by all accounts, accomplish much this spring. But one of the things it did do, legislators now acknowledge, was make a major mistake.
 When legislators passed the state budget in May, they agreed to raise fees, or invent new ones, for cases being filed in State Supreme Court. But the legislation, intended to raise revenue, was written so vaguely -- and, legislators believe, hastily -- that the fees also apply to New York City Housing Court, the often chaotic last refuge of the city's poorest residents and working class. 
 Starting Monday, housing court plaintiffs and defendants alike -- two groups with limited financial resources who fight over life's basics such as adequate heat in winter and timely rent payments -- will be facing hundreds of dollars in additional costs, new hurdles that some fear will effectively bar them from access to the court.
For instance, it will cost a tenant or landlord $45 to file any and every motion in cases, when it used to cost nothing. The legislation, for the first time, also institutes a fee for actually settling a case.
The mix-up has set off a scramble to undo one of the few things Albany actually did. Leaders in both the Assembly and the Senate are pledging to introduce corrective legislation upon their return in September. At least two lawsuits are expected to be filed as soon as today, seeking an injunction against the fees' implementation.
The lawsuits, in a rare moment of agreement, are being supported by both landlord and tenant groups.
Not surprisingly, doubts abound.
"Even if everyone wants it to happen, will it really happen? I never rely on them to do anything," Judith Goldiner, a staff lawyer for the Legal Aid Society, said of state legislators.
Others had an even more sinister view of what happened in Albany.
"Either it was tremendous negligence or stupidity, or it was deliberate," said Samuel J. Himmelstein, a lawyer for many city tenants.
With its boisterous atmosphere of lawyers and tenants negotiating in crowded hallways or barking into cellphones, the housing court can be a desperately bewildering experience. While about 90 percent of the landlords have lawyers, perhaps only 15 percent of the tenants do. And because the hearings before the judges, who are among the most overworked in the system, are typically brief, litigants often have just a few minutes to summarize their predicaments.
Last year, New York had more than 374,000 housing court cases. In recent years, the number of evictions has gradually declined, but the orders to show cause -- legal motions that are typically filed by tenants seeking to buy more time to pay off back rent -- have jumped markedly, increasing by 39 percent between 1998 and 2002.
The introduction of new, and not widely known, fees, veterans of the court say, will add one more layer of confusion and, perhaps, despair.
The city's housing court is part of the civil court system, and is separate from the criminal system. But state law says that any fees imposed on the criminal system apply to civil courts, too.
And that is the law that legislators claim they were unaware of when they agreed, in the final budget deal, to increase the fees for State Supreme Court filings to help generate up to $50 million more for the state's coffers.
Toward the end of the session, both the Assembly and the Senate passed bills that would have exempted civil courts from the new fees. But, as with so many initiatives in Albany, the bills did not match. Now, there is talk in both the Senate and the Assembly of taking up the issue again in September.
"Obviously, there would be dramatic consequences if this takes effect," said Assemblywoman Helene E. Weinstein, a Brooklyn Democrat who heads the judiciary committee. "But I remain optimistic that there is at least the potential for a nonlegislative temporary solution to prevent this from even going forward."
One such recourse is a lawsuit. And two are expected to be filed before Monday on the grounds that the statute was too ambiguous and that the Legislature never intended it to apply to housing court: one by the firm of Borah, Goldstein, Altschuler, Schwartz & Nahins, on behalf of the Rent Stabilization Association, which represents small landlords; and the other by the firm of Sokolski & Zekaria, which is representing landlords and tenants in Brooklyn and Manhattan.
"Housing court is an expensive, unfortunate part of the court system, and anything that adds to that is not beneficial," said Robert D. Goldstein of Borah Goldstein.
On Tuesday, several dozen lawyers representing landlords and tenants met with Fern A. Fisher, the administrative judge of the New York City Civil Court, which oversees the housing court. And there, according to Judge Fisher and several participants, lawyers expressed concerns about how the new legislation could give parties less incentive to negotiate, resulting in more trials and more delays.
And while the city's poorest tenants would likely be exempt from paying the new fees, there are more working-class and even upper-middle-class professionals who are ending up in housing court, largely because of the sour economy.
"There are union members who I represent who will be evicted because they don't have the $45 filing fee," said Bill Whalen, a supervising lawyer with District Council 37 of the Municipal Employees Legal Services.
For her part, Judge Fisher sounded sympathetic to those concerns, and the potential logistical nightmare involving people confused about the new rules. "It's very difficult to implement, and it will have an impact on the public," she said.
Through it all, many lawyers have been critical of what they say has been the noncommittal reaction from the Office of Court Administration, which oversees the entire court system and had strongly pushed for the new fee structure for the State Supreme Court. But David Bookstaver, a spokesman for the Office of Court Administration, said that such concerns had not been ignored.
"There is a concerted effort to address this issue, and toexplore various avenues on how to proceed," he said.
Still, some lawyers said they were not optimistic that any substantive changes would be forthcoming. After all, there are rough estimates that the new fees on housing court could net the state $10 million to $30 million a year.
"We don't really trust the people who are telling us this stuff anymore," Mr. Himmelstein, the tenants' lawyer, said, talking about both legislators in Albany and court officials. "Once the money starts flowing, in today's times, who's going to cut it off?"
