HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Master Plan Nears for an Abandoned Snuff Mill Site

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
WHEN he was a boy visiting his grandmother's house in Helmetta, Andrew Tancredi recalls, the snuff mill across the street made the whole town smell sweet. "The flavor going into the tobacco," he said, "was always in the air."
 But then, those were generally sweeter times for Helmetta, noted Mr. Tancredi, who now lives in his late grandmother's home; in those days, the mill was thriving -- and so was the town built around it. Now, as president of the Helmetta Borough Council, Mr. Tancredi is one of those presiding over an effort to make the mill site into something vital again. 
 Helmetta, off Route 18 in Middlesex County, had its beginnings in 1880 when George W. Helme, a New Orleans lawyer and Confederate major general, bought the land between Spotswood and Jamesburg for a snuff processing mill and 105 homes for mill workers. He named the land after his daughter, Olivia Antoinette Helme, who was known as Etta. In 1888, Mr. Helme led a secession from East Brunswick, and the borough of Helmetta was officially established. 
By 1925, the Helme Snuff Mill in Helmetta claimed to be the world's largest producer of snuff -- powdered tobacco that was snorted or applied to the gums -- and snuff-related products, like chewing tobacco. By 1934, the mill employed 400 people, most of them residents of Helmetta.
Swisher International, a large tobacco company based in West Virginia, later took over the plant and ran it successfully until 1993. Then Swisher moved all its operations south and shut down the old factory in Helmetta, vacating 16 brick and frame buildings on 31 acres -- smack at the middle of Main Street. Left behind, too, were 1,200 residents, virtually all of whom had had connections with the mill.
"The mill has been a blight on the center of town ever since," said Frank Hague, the mayor of Helmetta, who moved to the tiny town, 20 miles from Trenton and bordering on Spotswood, the year the factory closed. "The loss of property taxes and jobs was devastating." 
Helmetta has managed to get by, and even to grow, without the business that was its namesake and primary taxpayer, the town officials said. The addition of 400 condominiums and town houses several years ago helped swell the population to about 1,825, Mayor Hague said.
"But we spent a decade waiting and hoping that Swisher would find someone to purchase the mill and redevelop it," he said. "Nothing happened."
The vacant buildings were not vandalized and did not become a home for derelicts. "This is like Mayberry," the mayor said, "even though it's in the busiest part of the state. It's a nice, small, quiet town, with crab apple trees lining the streets. Our borough hall is the old schoolhouse. We have a small-town police force, and the people are respectful. It is just a waste to have the mill buildings sitting there empty." 
Finally, he said, Helmetta moved to put its own plan in the works -- a master plan for redevelopment that would turn the site into a residential and commercial center, or, maybe, a conference center.
Last year, the town began refurbishing its downtown park, situated near the mill and adjacent to Helmetta Pond, which is known to botanists for its unusual plant life. A fishing pier, walking trails and a gazebo are being installed in the park, using state and county grant money.
Meanwhile, the town declared the Helme site "an area in need of redevelopment," the first step in setting up a redevelopment area over which it will have control. It also hired Remington, Vernick & Vena Engineers and Planners, based in Toms River, to come up with a blueprint for transforming the mill property -- as long as two main mill buildings on Main Street were preserved. Last month, the firm produced its first draft, which awaits review by the town Planning Board and, if approved, by the council. The mayor and the council president say they have already looked at the plan, though, and they are thrilled.
"This redevelopment plan is exactly what we were looking for," Mr. Hague said. "It outlines our goals, and it leaves things flexible as to exactly which way we go."
Mr. Hague said about 10 developers had already contacted him about the project, for which the town may not officially solicit proposals until after the redevelopment plan is in place. The developers have floated different sorts of ideas for reviving the site, he said.
Stuart Wiser of Remington & Vernick, who is in charge of producing the redevelopment plan, said, "Its overriding philosophy is flexibility."
He added, "While we are confident that Helmetta's ideal character, its Middlesex County location, and its proximity to the economic and population centers of central and northern New Jersey will create a tremendous demand for residential and commercial space, we did not want to lock ourselves into a single project type."
The proposed plan suggests two possibilities, one residential-based and the other more commercially oriented. The first envisions a mixed-use residential complex with "appropriate commercial amenities," like a supermarket, drugstore and shopping, while the second envisions a conference center and hotel with amenities appropriate to that use.
Mr. Tancredi said he was an early supporter of the conference center concept, which he thinks takes advantage of the borough's countrified setting and central New Jersey location.
"We are within 5 or 10 minutes of every major highway in this part of the state," he said, "and 5 or 10 minutes from Exit 8A off the Turnpike. There is a huge number of warehouses doing business in the area around us -- and aside from the Marriott Inn in Cranbury, there is no specialty place like a conference center in the area. It could be a place to be rented out for weddings, too. There's always a call for that."
IN Mr. Tancredi's view, if housing is put on the mill site, it should be restricted to older adults. Helmetta now pays the town of Spotswood to educate its 240 schoolchildren, but Spotswood schools are close to capacity, Mr. Tancredi said. "The question has to be asked, Would it be irresponsible to send more kids there than is already necessary?"
While remaining flexible on the use of the site, town officials do appear to be firm about saving the larger mill buildings, especially the two seven-story main structures that are closest to Main Street. The redevelopment plan calls for, and "strongly encourages," the rehabilitation and adaptive reuse of some of the existing structures, while permitting alteration or demolition of others deemed not reusable.
"Several of the two- and three-story buildings that were used to hang and dry the tobacco still have that tobacco smell worked into the wood," Mr. Hague said. "Some are old and shabby, although the two main buildings don't have a brick out of place." 
The proposed redevelopment plan specifies that any new construction is to reflect the mill's historic architecture. Helmetta has its own Historical Society, whose members collect memorabilia from the mill and its products, and who feel they have a stake in keeping its history alive, the mayor said.
"The mill is the reason we're here," he said, "and that won't be forgotten."

HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE LIFE: THE BOSS; 
A Sports Guy's Credo

BYLINE:  By EWALD KIST; Written with Joseph B. Treaster.

 BODY:
TOWARD the end of World War II, life in my country, the Netherlands, was very difficult. The last winter was what they called the hungry winter. It was so bad that people ate tulip bulbs. The Germans had kicked my parents out of their house, and they were living with three other families. I was 1 year old.
 Once a month, you could get an egg. If you had a baby, you got an extra egg. Everyone living in the house would share the extra egg they'd gotten because of me. They would split it into 14 pieces. 
 After the war, the Americans helped us with aid through the Marshall Plan. It got the machinery going again. I think that's why the Dutch are always friendly and thankful toward the American people.
As an adult, I've come to believe in a work-life balance. There's more on earth than just money. I am 59 years old and the father of five children. My wife, like me, is a lawyer. And I am a sports lover, a sports guy. I played on the national field hockey team; we went to the Olympics in Mexico in 1968. I've run in six marathons.
I met my wife at a teammate's wedding. I ran my first marathon in Washington, when I was in charge of ING's North American operations. In the United States, field hockey was not considered a man's sport. So at the age of 45, I switched sports. I've run in three New York City marathons, the latest with three of my sons. And since we now are the title sponsor of the ING New York marathon, I plan to participate next year with all four of my sons.
Through sports I learned to be a team player and to go for the gold. I keep my body healthy with sports. And I set an example for my employees by engaging in activities outside the office. I'm not impressed by workaholics.
I've learned to be very efficient. In my early years, I took speed-reading courses. I can boil down my whole job to four categories: important things and unimportant things, urgent things and not-urgent things. The slow, unimportant things I leave to one side; many solve themselves.
My father was a Supreme Court judge in the Netherlands. It was an important job, but the pay was poor. We were five children; there was no money for travel, but field hockey opened the world for me. I traveled to India, Pakistan and Mexico. 
When I graduated from Leiden University, I was drafted into the Dutch Army as a lieutenant. It was my first management job. Our job was to keep the Russians out, and they never came. I had to find ways to motivate my people. For training, we had a small, unmanned plane that towed a big white blanket as a target. We tried to shoot at the target. The troops loved it. The lesson is that to get people to do things, you need to make things useful and fun.
After the army, I entered a training program at National Nederlanden, a predecessor of ING. I've worked at the company for 34 years.
Skating is another sport of mine. You may have heard about the 11-Cities Tour in Holland. I participated twice. This is a 200-kilometer skating tour over lakes and canals with some 25.000 participants. It is like a New York City marathon, but on ice. Extremely cold. Terrible winds.
A marathon is only four hours, but this lasts all day and late into the night. The hardship is extreme. You are exhausted, as in a marathon. Three-quarters of the way through a marathon you ask yourself, "What am I doing here?" People are falling down from exhaustion. But you have to have the guts to go farther and to spread your energy over the whole trip. That's the art.

GRAPHIC: Photo: EWALD KIST -- Chief of the ING Group, the financial services company (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Behind the Region's Run-Up in Prices 

BYLINE:  By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
THE value of homes in the New York metropolitan area has risen faster than homes in almost all other areas in the country for more than five years, providing a bounteous reward to anyone with the foresight or luck to already own a home, but raising questions about the impact of the high prices on home seekers and housing policies. 
 Across the region, the median sale price of a single-family home has risen by 75 percent since 1998, an increase of more than $140,000, according to data collected by the National Association of Realtors. Across the country, prices have risen 26 percent in that time. 
 Of 139 separate geographic areas tracked in the price survey, the entire New York region ranked fifth in percentage gain. But Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island ranked first in the country during this period, with home prices nearly doubling; the median price of all homes sold in the two counties increased by $162,000, to $338,000. Long Island was followed by the Sacramento and San Diego areas, and then Monmouth and Ocean Counties along the Jersey shore. Bergen and Passaic Counties in northern New Jersey ranked ninth. 
At times in recent years, there have been frenzied bidding wars, with houses selling within days if not hours after being placed on the market. But more recently, brokers say, price increases are moderating; supplies of homes for sale -- especially more expensive homes -- are increasing; and the market is becoming what brokers say is "more balanced," albeit at the highest median prices ever.
"The worst you can say about housing prices is that the rate of price increases is slowing," said Rae Rosen, a regional economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "To me the continued price appreciation reflects the underlying strength of the economy in the metropolitan area. People are voting with their feet. They are saying we are staying here and paying premium prices to do so."
The surge in prices here during a period of economic weakness is the product of many factors, both national -- notably, extraordinarily low interest rates -- and local, such as a slowing in the construction of new homes, especially moderately priced ones, and a critical lack of land for new home construction.
Together, these trends raise concerns for some homeowners and home seekers. Will prices stagnate, and in some cases fall, as they did in much of the region in the early 1990's after a huge run-up in pricesduring the previous decade? Will young families today with average middle class incomes be able to afford homes in the region? What will happen if interest rates rise as high as they were a few years ago?
For Patricia Green, a senior assistant dean in the Frank G. Zarb School of Business at Hofstra, the rising housing market worked out just right. After completing her doctorate in educational administration, she was recently hired as an associate dean at Ithaca College in upstate New York and it was time to sell the house she shared with her mother and two dogs.
Her father had purchased a Cape Cod home in the original Long Island Levittown in 1952 for $6,700; it was modestly expanded some time later, but the kitchen had never been updated. 
It was put on the market for $299,990, a price her broker, Michael Litzner of Century 21 American Homes, thought would appeal to an entry-level home buyer with income of $80,000 to $100,000. The property attracted immediate interest, since more extensively remodeled Levittown homes cost upward of $100,000 more.
The potential buyers "were every age, every type of person," Dr. Green said. "There were some single women, some couples with children, some without children, older people, a racial and ethnic mix. Some were moving from condos, some moving to be closer where they worked. I had five buyers on the weekend after Memorial Day, preapproved."
By the end of Sunday, the house was sold for $300,000, $10 more than the asking price, enough to pay for a much larger house along Cayuga Lake in Ithaca with a mortgage with 5.2 percent interest.
Brokers in many parts of the region say $300,000 homes have gone the way of the 10-cent telephone call. And where homes in this price range are available, they sell quickly and are in short supply, while inventories of much higher-priced homes are rising.
For first-time buyers, the situation can be bleak. "They call you and you feel bad for them," said Sharon Tucker of Tucker Associates GMAC Real Estate in West Nyack in Rockland County. "They just got married, they are in the city and they have been renting. These homes are tough to find. You might be able to show them three or four homes, and their apartments are bigger."
A "decent little house" in Nanuet is $375,000 to $380,000, she said. Instead, she suggests a condominium in Valley Cottage for $219,000 plus $350 in monthly maintenance and $4,500 in property taxes a year.
A few years back in Clifton, N.J., Diana Bustamante of Keller Williams Team Realty sold a very nice, but small, Cape Cod house on Surrey Lane for $204,000 and, she recalled, "people thought I was a miracle maker."
Now, she said, a similar two-bedroom Cape on Lyall Road, a few blocks away, is on the market for $289,000 in a neighborhood that attracts many first-time home buyers, frequently immigrants who had been living in New York City and Hudson County. To find a larger house with a driveway and a garage in a "nice neighborhood" is nearly impossible for less than $300,000, she said.
"There are not enough properties on the market for the number of buyers out there," Ms. Bustamante said. "Where were these buyers 10 years ago? We had too many houses and not enough buyers."
In Mercer County, John Burke, manager of the Gloria Nilson GMAC Real Estate office in Hamilton, said that though the number of multiple offers on properties had declined, they were still common. "There are times that we scratch our heads trying to justify the prices," he said.

Source of the Surge
Dramatic Impact Of Falling Rates
The driving force behind the surge in prices here and across the country has been sharply falling mortgage interest rates, as the Federal Reserve Bank responded to the weakness in the economy by driving rates to their lowest levels in more than 30 years.
It is hard to overestimate the impact of these falling interest rates on the housing market. It was as if the Federal Reserve Bank had put tens of thousands of dollars in the pocket of nearly every home buyer in the country: every qualified buyer could get a larger loan, based on his or her income, at no extra cost.
Mortgage interest rates began rising in the late 1990's as the stock market took off and peaked in May 2000, at a monthly average of 8.52 percent for a 30-year mortgage, before falling to 5.23 percent last month, according to Freddie Mac.
A buyer who put down 20 percent in cash and who was willing to pay $2,000 a month in mortgage payments would have been able to afford a $325,000 house in the year 2000, but today would be able to afford a $454,000 house, a extra $129,000 or 40 percent, in purchasing power over a short period. Of course, the down payment would be almost $26,000 larger.
The lower interest rates enabled many homeowners to refinance their mortgages and either reduce payments or borrow more cash without increasing their monthly payments, or both. And even homeowners who did nothing saw their homes rise in value.
This extra purchasing power brought many thousands of new buyers into the home market. Others rushed to trade up. People who had never been able to qualify for mortgages suddenly were in the market. Prices rose, and across the country many more new homes were constructed. 
Economists say the tremendous wealth effect for those who owned homes provided some comfort in the face of stock market losses, including those in 401(k) retirement plans of people who did not otherwise dabble in the stock market, and protected the economy from a deeper recession.
The effect of this can be seen in statistics that track the mortgage payments needed to support the median priced home in the metropolitan area. Despite sharp increases in these prices, the mortgage needed to support the typical home has risen far less, and after controlling for the cost of living has actually declined from the late 1980's. 
Since the year 2000, median prices in the New York area have increased 43 percent, but the monthly mortgage payment needed to carry that home increased only 14 percent, to $1,552, and only 7 percent after accounting for inflation.
By June, when mortgage rates fell further, the mortgage on that same median house would have declined by $100 a month. Even more striking, since 1990 prices have increased by nearly 90 percent but mortgage payments have actually declined by 11 percent after accounting for inflation.

New York Region
Where Supply Is Lagging
The interest rate bounty does little to explain why housing prices are rising faster in the New York metropolitan area than elsewhere in the country. To economists, the answer can be summarized by a simple economic proposition: supply and demand.
In much of the country, the supply of housing is expanding to meet the demand. In the New York region and in a few densely populated areas on both coasts that is not happening.
David A. Lereah, the chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, said that the run-up in prices is not evidence of a "bubble" similar to the Internet stock market frenzy, but the functioning of a rational marketplace.
"The supply of homes is very, very lean in New York," he said. "That is why you have such huge price appreciation. That is a healthy thing."
He said that around New York construction of new homes has not kept pace with job creation over the last decade. "Something has to give," he said, "so prices go up."
He said that over 10 years, one home has been created for every 1.6 jobs created nationally, but in the New York metropolitan area one home has been created for about every 16 new jobs. He estimated it would take an additional 269,007 homes in the New York area to meet the needs created by a decade of economic growth.
The comparison between the New York region and the Atlanta metropolitan area, which leads the country in new home construction, is stark. In Atlanta, one single-family home building permit was issued for every 81 residents last year, compared with one for every 735 residents in the New York area, including suburban counties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, according to the Census Bureau. When multifamily dwellings are included, the ratio shifts to one unit for every 61 residents of Atlanta, compared with one unit for every 378 in the New York region.
The New York area, analysts say, is running out of land for large housing developments. The new homes that are being built -- not infrequently by knocking down older homes -- are marketed to more affluent buyers of large homes.
When a new home is built, it typically frees up an older, lower-priced home that is also put on the market. When fewer homes are built, this trickle-down effect is weaker. At the price range that many first-time homeowners can afford, there are few homes to be had.
Michael H. Schill, a law professor and director of the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at New York University, worries that the "smart growth" movement in some New York suburbs, which seeks to protect open spaces and limit sprawl in outlying areas through restrictive zoning, is cutting into the supply of land for housing. In theory, high-density developments are supposed to compensate for land left undeveloped, but proposals for such developments are often fiercely resisted.
"If you limit the amount of land that can be used for housing, there is no surer way of getting higher home prices," he said. "It is transferring wealth from renters and people getting into the market to upper income people."
The demand for lower priced homes may be so extreme and the supply so limited that it is distorting statistics in the New York area and perhaps exaggerating the median price increase, according to some housing analysts and appraisers.
The median price data compiled by the National Association of Realtors is based mainly on prices at closings reported by local multiple listing services used by brokers across the country. It is the most current national housing price survey, although it excludes sales by owners and exclusive sales not reported to the listing services. 
Jeffrey G. Otteau, the president of the Otteau Appraisal Group, which publishes market reports for much of New Jersey, said the housing picture "is not quite as optimistic" as the closely followed median price figures suggest.
When the New Jersey Board of Realtors recently published figures showing continuing double-digit increases in median prices in Ocean and Monmouth Counties, he concluded that most of the houses sold were new homes in "luxury price ranges," while more down-to-earth homes were hard to find. Thus, the median-price home, with half of all sales higher and half lower, moved upward.
"Most builders wish they could find land for lower priced homes, but municipalities don'twant it," he said. "The trend is that most are increasing their minimum lot size requirements."
He estimated, based on recent transactions, that the true price increases in New Jersey this year will be far lower than in recent years, closer to 5 percent. 
The same pattern may hold in Westchester County, where 2,200 building permits were reported last year, including 1,049 for single-family homes. The new construction is barely enough to replace homes lost through fires and demolition, according to P. Gilbert Mercurio, chief executive of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. 
In Westchester, he said, inventory was up and sales were down, but, contrary to the usual functioning of supply and demand, median prices remain higher than ever. 
Mary Ellen Tolan, a broker in the Scarsdale office of Houlihan/Lawrence, said that inventory is rising for the most expensive properties, while there was little available at the lower end of the market, which in Scarsdale is $500,000 to $600,000. "There is softness at anything over $2 million," she said. "Sellers have been holding the line, but we are starting to see some compromise."
A similar pattern is evident in the Manhattan condominium and co-op market. Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, an appraisal company, said that prices currently seem to be rising over levels of a year ago but that there was a quarter-to-quarter price decline in the first quarter of this year. In that period, prices of the properties in the highest 10 percent of the market fell more, by 11.5 percent, than the overall median, which declined by 1.9 percent.

Looking Ahead
Weighing the Effects Of Increases in Rates
But what happens when mortgage interest rates stop falling and start to rise? Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, remembers the local real estate boom in the early 1980's, followed by years of static and even declining prices in the recession in the early 1990's, and says the current market is risky for anyone who buys now and needs to sell within a year or two. 
Although many economists forecast a modest rise in interest rates during the second half of this year, they say that it will probably have little effect on the housing market. If rates rise as part of a broad economic recovery, incomes will rise too, limiting the impact on home prices and values.
Under this theory, buyers will then have to pay more each month to cover the cost of a new home purchase, but will have more income available. Unless the local economy hits some unexpected bumps, they say, the demand for homes by aging baby boomers and immigrant families will probably continue as well.
The lack of inventory of moderately priced homes is having a ripple effect across the region. 
In the Bronx, demand is keen but inventory low, according to Joseph F. Limongelli, a broker at Better Homes Realty and president of the Bronx-Manhattan North Association of Realtors. 
He said that homeowners in the East Bronx, Throgs Necks and surrounding areas are finding housing in the suburbs more expensive to buy and to own, because of higher taxes, and are staying in the Bronx. In Throgs Neck, a one-family row house is selling for about $310,000, and larger three-bedroom houses for $350,000. "People are staying put rather than moving to the suburbs," he said. "A lot of them are improving what they have and staying."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
New Kind of Snooping Arrives at the Office

BYLINE:  By MARCI ALBOHER NUSBAUM

 BODY:
CORPORATE executives are becoming increasingly aggressive about spying on their employees, and with good reason: now, in addition to job shirkers and office-supply thieves, they have to worry about being held accountable for the misconduct of their subordinates.
 Even one offensive e-mail message circulated around the office by a single employee can pose a liability risk for a company. Not only that, but a wave of laws -- including the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 and the anticorruption and corporate-governance Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 -- have imposed new record-keeping and investigative burdens on companies. Not complying with some laws can result in the personal liability of officers and directors. 
 As a result, employers have stepped up their surveillance of employees, often using stealth techniques to peer deep into their computer use. As of 2001, more than a third of all American workers with access to computers, or 14 million in all, were being monitored in one way or another, according to the Privacy Foundation, a Denver research group; with added pressure on executives to oversee their employees' electronic activities, experts predict that those numbers will grow.
Indeed, while companies still use cameras and phone taps to track down the bad eggs and sometimes even send detectives into the office to poke around for evidence after hours, most scrutiny focuses on computers, the weapon of choice for corporate wrongdoers.
A growing band of specialists in a field called human-resource forensics are using the latest technology to record everything from the Web sites employees visit to the files they delete to the data they download, even as workplace and legal experts are raising red flags about some of those efforts.
Though some forms of surveillance are perfectly proper, they say, using technology to spy on employees can damage workplace morale and, if taken to extremes, test the boundaries of what is ethical or legal. At the very least, these experts urge companies to think hard before turning their workplaces into areas where no one feels trusted.
The key, says Arthur G. Tisi, chief executive of atthought.com, a technology-services company in Tarrytown, N.Y., is being consistent and "maintaining a moral compass."
The most important decision for companies to make, Mr. Tisi says, is whether extensive surveillance will violate the corporate culture or otherwise be counterproductive. "For example, if your institution is all about freedom of information and you're monitoring your employees, there is an obvious conflict," he said.
If a company monitors employees' activities, Mr. Tisi says, it should identify the reason why: whether it is to gauge employee productivity, contain costs, fight corporate espionage or comply with legal requirements. He also suggests formulating a policy and creating a committee of people from all parts of the organization to implement it.
Margaret Blair Soyster, an employment lawyer in New York with the law firm Clifford Chance, says that employers should have a written policy advising employees that their e-mail messages are not private but can be read by their supervisors, that the technology they use at work belongs to the company and that the company reserves the right to monitor the computer activities of employees.
"It should also make it explicit that technology shouldn't be used in any way that could contribute to a hostile work environment," she said, adding that even circulating off-color jokes through e-mail could fall into this category. "And employees should sign off on the policy."
SUCH precautions probably make it easier for companies to deal with troublemakers without becoming embroiled in legal disputes, experts say. Ms. Soyster recalled the case of a company that tracked employees' movements within the building electronically and discovered that an especially unproductive employee spent excessive hours at work. It then examined his computer use and concluded he was visiting Internet pornography sites for six or seven hours a day.
Confronted, the employee tried a novel defense. "His response was that he had a sexual compulsion that was a disability that the company needed to accommodate," Ms. Soyster said.
Ultimately, he left the company without pursuing his claim, but Ms. Soyster said she believed that the ability to monitor his activities had helped the client get rid of an unproductive employee and contain a potential liability -- the risk that another employee would complain that the man's activities had created a hostile work environment.
Even the decision to monitor the e-mail system, something that most employees have come to expect, is not without risks.
"Companies have to be careful about what they are watching for," said Clifford R. Atlas, an employment lawyer in New York with the law firm Jackson Lewis. "If there's union organizing going on, then acts of surveillance can lead to an unfair-labor-practices charge."
Some companies are engaged in what might be called surveillance light, hiring third parties to question employees about their concerns and seek out information from them. One such service provider is eePulse of Ann Arbor, Mich.
Some queries are open-ended, like, "What issues are you having at work?" Others seek particular information, like whether employees have witnessed improper behavior in their departments. Employees respond directly to eePulse, which compiles the data and returns information to the company without revealing the identity of individual respondents.
Theresa M. Welbourne, eePulse's chief executive, said the employees her company contacted via its Measurecom software were often wary at first, but warmed up to the task once they realized that their participation was voluntary and that the confidentiality of their responses was guaranteed.
"We perform a different kind of audit," Dr. Welbourne said. "If you look at some of the big scandals lately, if they had our kind of data, we could have known about it a long time ago."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Sarah Massey, William Leggett

 BODY:
Sarah Elizabeth Massey, a daughter of Dr. Marilyn Chapin Massey and James A. Massey of Paris, was married last evening to William Hinch Leggett, the son of Jane Hinch Leggett of Flushing, Queens, and the late William W. Leggett. The Rev. Susan Marlan, an interfaith minister, officiated at the New York Aquarium in Brooklyn. 
 Ms. Massey, 29, is keeping her name. She is the communications director of the National Employment Law Project in Manhattan, an advocacy organization for the unemployed and working poor. She graduated from the State University College at Cortland, N.Y., and received a master's degree in urban planning from Hunter. Her father retired as an actor in Los Angeles. Her mother, also retired, was the president of Pitzer College in Claremont, Calif. 
 Mr. Leggett, 32, teaches English at Forest Hills High School in Queens. He also graduated from Cortland and received a master's degree in English literature at the C.W. Post campus of Long Island University. His mother retired from the Department of Corrections as a chaplain at the Rose M. Singer Correctional Facility for Women on Riker's Island. His father covered horse racing for Sports Illustrated.
Ms. Massey and Mr. Leggett met in 1994 at Cortland, when they were dialogue partners in a Spanish class, which led to studying together.
One day, he stuck a note in a fortune cookie. As Ms. Massey recalled, "It said, 'You will go out with a handsome young man and make him very happy,' and I thought, of course."
But it did not last. Ms. Massey said, "We were young -- I was 21, Bill was 24 -- and I don't think I was ready for a major commitment."
In 1999, a college friend asked if she knew what had become of Mr. Leggett. "We hadn't spoken for four years," Ms. Massey remembered. "I wrote him a letter that night, and basically in the letter I said, I'm well, I hope you're well. Basically, I apologized." 
She mailed the letter on a Monday, and by that Friday she received two single-spaced typed pages, with his telephone number. She called that night, and they talked for hours, ending with a plan to go to the Bronx Zoo the next Monday.
On opening the door and seeing him, Ms. Massey realized she wanted to pick up where she had left off. "I remember the moment. I almost fell over. He was dressed real nice, and he didn't look like a kid anymore -- he looked like a man. And he was wearing the cologne I had given him, four years later."

HEADLINE: SENIORITY; 
A Soft Landing for the Boomers?

BYLINE:  By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the second Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS baby boomers face retirement, they have a problem of their own making. This often-pampered and self-indulgent generation is unprepared financially. Instead of saving, too many of them have mortgaged their futures for a BMW lifestyle.
 The latest figures from the Federal Reserve show that the median net worth -- or difference between assets and liabilities -- is $123,684 for families whose household heads are 45 to 54 years old. That means that half the families have more than this amount and half have less. The average net worth for the group is $419,073, but the median is probably more representative because income distribution in the United States is heavily skewed toward the top, a trend that has been accelerating in recent years. 
 These assets, especially the median figure, do not point to lavish retirements, and the clock is ticking. Boomers are turning 50 at the rate of seven every minute and will continue to do so until 2014, according to American Demographics magazine.
Of course, it's wrong to generalize excessively about this generation of70 million or so people. Dr. Robert N. Butler, the president of the International Longevity Center-USA, a research organization in Manhattan, has observed that the quintessential upscale baby-boomer lifestyle often depicted in the media tends to be a coastal phenomenon; in the center of the country, boomers are almost indistinguishable from the rest of the population.
No one should generalize, either, about how much money people need to retire comfortably, despite the mutual fund industry's self-serving estimate that it will take at least 70 percent of your annual preretirement income.
Deena Katz, 53, an independent financial adviser and the president of Evensky, Brown & Katz, a financial planning firm in Coral Gables, Fla., has some definite opinions about her generation. She says the fundamental difference between baby boomers and their parents is in the philosophy of and approach to "things."
"The big issue for baby boomers is that they live in the immediate now," she said. "They have always given themselves everything they thought they were entitled to. When my folks needed a refrigerator, they saved money and bought it. Notice I said 'needed,' not 'wanted.' Now, when boomers want a refrigerator, they buy it and pay it off over time.
"So the boomers are absolutely going to have a hard time making an adjustment to a downsized lifestyle, because they haven't saved enough to continue as they have been living."
But many will have to make that adjustment, and she expects the boomers to solve the problem in a way typical of their generation: they will change the rules.
"I don't think the boomers will be a generation of traditional retirees," Ms. Katz said. "We will be a generation of repositioning."
"Repositioning" is another way of saying that the boomers will continue to work in some fashion and will stay very active in their version of "retirement" -- as has been indicated in most surveys.
BUT what about the generation's resistance to giving up "things" and living a less expensive life?
"They are going to have to make some sacrifices and changes," Ms. Katz said. "And that will work for them if they are convinced these changes are positive rather than negative."
She also says that many baby boomers and others who maintain that they don't want to move to a less expensive part of the country when they retire will actually do so when the time comes. A recent survey by Harris Interactive for Del Webb, the big builder of retirement communities, may support that notion. In the April survey, 59 percent of baby boomers aged 44 to 56 said they would relocate in retirement; in a similar survey in 1999, only 31 percent of those from 48 to 52 said they would do so.
"We'll see a great exodus from the cities into a simpler, less complicated lifestyle," she said. "But it will be a positive thing for the boomers -- not, 'You're going to have to sacrifice and downsize!' but, 'I want to make my life simpler and the plus in that is that it's going to cost me less.' This will be their salvation from the problem of not having saved enough. When the mutual fund industry says you can't retire on less than 70 percent of your preretirement income, the boomers will say, 'Not me, baby; I'm going to figure it out.' "
The differences in housing prices around the country show why boomers might be willing to move.
Whenever I check home prices on the Internet, in newspapers or in real estate booklets, I am astounded by the low prices outside major metropolitan areas, particularly when I look away from the East or West Coasts. That $300,000 you might pay for a small house in the New York or San Francisco areas will buy much more in Arkansas or New Mexico.
Last winter, I took a car trip through the eastern part of West Virginia, then south through the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia. I picked up several real estate booklets along the way. While plenty of homes were listed in the $200,000-to-$300,000 range, there were also these:
* A new home on a one-acre wooded lot. It had three bedrooms, two baths, vaulted ceilings, a fully equipped kitchen, a fireplace, a basement and a deck with a hot tub. The asking price was $149,900.
* A two-story log home on five acres. Three bedrooms and two baths. $95,000.
* A ranch house on 1.77 acres. Three bedrooms, two baths, a fireplace, deck and a double garage. $119,000. 
Of course, these houses have probably been sold by now, and comparable houses may have risen a bit in price. They may not match your personal tastes or be in areas where you want to live, but you get the idea.
A good Web site for home prices nationwide is www.realtor.com. To compare costs of living, including home prices, among most cities and towns, try www.BestPlaces.net. It's an eye-opener for coastal boomers.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Economic Slump Hits Men the Hardest

BYLINE:  By Steven Greenhouse

 BODY:
EVEN though the pay wasn't great, Michael Deloach, 41, was happy with his $7-an-hour job as a messenger for a Wall Street firm. It was steady, full-time work; he felt needed, and he was not expecting anything better because he was a high-school dropout.
 Then came the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, and his firm laid him off, after four years on the job. Since then, Mr. Deloach has tried other messenger jobs but the work there was so unsteady and the pay so meager that he left them. Now he is looking for jobs as a security guard, janitor or messenger. "It's real hard out there because I have no computer skills and I don't have a G.E.D., and even if I did, it would still be hard," he said. 
 Mr. Deloach is the victim of a surprising twist in New York's economic slump -- it has hit men much harder then women. The industries in the city hit hardest by the downturn -- finance, software, airline and construction -- employ men disproportionately, and as a result the jobless rate for men has risen much faster than for women. 
The male jobless rate soared by 3.3 percentage points from 2000 to 2002, reaching an average of 8.8 percent in 2002, according to an analysis by the Community Service Society, a nonprofit group that serves the poor. Women fared considerably better, with their jobless rate rising by 1.5 percentage points to 7.6 percent in 2002.
"The rate for men tends to be more volatile because they're concentrated in blue-collar industries like manufacturing and construction, which go up and down with the job cycle," said James Brown, an economist with the New York State Department of Labor.
The job picture for women was brighter, largely because there was little job shrinkage in three major fields where women are employed disproportionately -- health services, education and social services. In those three areas, women represent more than 70 percent of the work force in the city, including 82 percent in social services, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"It isn't so much which industries have been losing employment so much as which industries have managed to gain employment throughout the recession, and those have been education, health and social services, which have been the mainstays of women's employment, particularly for less well-educated women," said Mark Levitan, senior policy analyst at the Community Service Society. 
A stark way of seeing how hard men in New York have been hit is to examine the employment-population ratio -- the percentage of men, aged 16 to 64, who are holding jobs. On average in 2002, the percentage of men with jobs dropped to 67.8 percent from 72.9 percent in 2000, a sharp 5.1 percentage points. In contrast, the ratio of women working fell by just 1.6 percentage points over those two years, to 56.8 percent.
The drop in the employment-population ratio for young men, age 16 through 24, was especially steep, falling by 9.7 percentage points, to just 36.4 percent. In contrast, the ratio for women age 16 to 24 fell just 1.2 percentage points, to 40.4 percent.
There was also a sharp decline for black and Hispanic men. Among working-age Hispanic men, the percentage with jobs fell by 7 percentage points to 65.5 percent, while for black men, the drop was 6.1 percentage points, to 58.1 percent. For black women, the employment rate fell just 1.1 percentage points, while for Hispanic women, the drop was 2.9 percentage points. 
Many labor force experts say young men with limited education are usually the last to be hired, and when the economy boomed in the 1990's, many found jobs. But when the economy weakened, they were often the first to be laid off. For men without a high school diploma, the percentage holding jobs fell 6.2 percentage points from 2000 to 2002.
"All this provides a clue to one mystery -- why the welfare rolls haven't been growing during this slump," said Mr. Levitan. "I don't want to say this is the answer, but it's part of the answer. The industries that have provided a lot of employment to less well-educated single mothers continued to grow through the recession -- health, education and social services."
But Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist with The New York STAT, an economic newsletter, said the good news for women may not last because fields like health and social services may soon make large-scale layoffs as the city and state grapple with their budget deficits. 
"The ability of women as a group to sidestep the worst of the recession may not last much longer," she said.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Detecting Signs of Life In Japan's Economy

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
AFTER more than a decade of watching the Japanese economy flounder and the stock market lose three-quarters of its value, many investors might not be willing to believe that a turn could be at hand.
 Still, the broadest stock market index, the Tokyo Price Index, has risen by more than 16 percent so far this year in dollar terms. Virtually all of that gain has come the last couple months. 
 Stephen Mitchell, who heads a team of Japanese equity specialists in London that manages about $5 billion at J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management, took some time last week to assess whether what is going on is real or another bear trap. Following are excerpts from the conversation: 

Q. Why do you think the Japanese stock market has turned?

A. Over the past two years, companies have been working at restructuring and improving their cash flow. That has gradually been coming through. Also, the Big Three Japanese auto companies are winning market share in the United States, Europe and are growing share in China.
Also, the government is extremely worried about a possible debt crisis. With little economic growth, there is not enough tax revenue to service the debt, which is more than 100 percent of Japan's gross domestic product. So they have to reflate the economy and keep the currency relatively weak. That reflation has started to come at the same time that balance sheets are improving.

Q. Have these efforts to stimulate the economy changed your economic forecast?

A. Currently, we are forecasting the economy will grow at a 1.2 percent rate, but we are in the process of revising our growth numbers higher.
We are looking for consumption, which is about half of gross domestic product in Japan, to start picking up. We have gotten the first glimmering of that in the last couple of months. But you can feel the energy beginning to pick up.

Q. Which sectors have been most successful in restructuring?

A. The number of sectors that have sorted themselves out is remarkable. Everything from shipbuilding to steel to rolling stock makers and plant engineers. Not only are the new industries doing well, but some of the old industries are coming back very strongly. In steel, for example, there are now only two big companies, which is a major change from a decade ago, when there were about 20.

Q. Have the problems in Japan's banking sector been resolved?

A. The banking situation is not resolved. They still have nonperforming loans to write down, and they are still undercapitalized. But big companies don't need to borrow from the banks. And small and medium-sized companies that need to borrow can go to a quasi-governmental lending organization to get access to capital. There is not a shortage of capital to grow.
In terms of their importance to the Japanese stock market, the banks, which used to represent about 24 percent of the market's capitalization, now make up about 7 percent. The five major city banks are now only about 3 percent of the market.

Q. How important is China in a Japanese recovery?

A. China is very important for Japan. It is a huge opportunity, and looks like a profitable one. The Japanese were relatively late coming to China, but they are moving in strongly now. The Chinese need machinery and capital equipment to bring their factories up to world standard, and Japanese manufacturers like Fanuc are providing that.
The other thing China needs is infrastructure, which means a boom for companies like Komatsu. China is their most profitable market. And the growth of the Chinese market is a real spur for Japanese shipping companies.

Q. Are Japanese stocks correctly valued?

A. We are about 75 percent below the 1989 peak. But valuations in Japan are in line with the global norm. Small-cap Japanese stocks are a bit cheap.
But at the moment, the market's capitalization is less than 60 percent of Japan's gross domestic product. That is about where it was in 1986. If you can snap the economy out of this deflationary spiral, you are going to have a market that is seriously cheap.

Q. Where are you putting your money?

A. Our focus in Japan is on manufacturing, which is where you are getting the profit recovery, and in the service sector, because it is underdeveloped compared to the United States and Europe.
In the service sector we like some of the labor outsourcing companies like Goodwill and Fullcast. 
In addition to Fanuc and Komatsu, other manufacturing companies we like are blue chips like Canon and Bridgestone. And we like a company like Nitto Denko, which is a supplier to the liquid-crystal display manufacturers.

HEADLINE: Business; 
In the Urban 7-Eleven, the Slurpee Looks Sleeker

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
THIS is not the 7-Eleven you grew up with.
 Gone are the garish red, orange and green stripes wrapping the top of the store. Gone, too, is the parking lot. Instead of anchoring a strip mall, this store is in a new, 48-story condominium building in the fashionable River North district of downtown Chicago, with a small 7-Eleven logo hanging from the sandstone facade. 
 Inside, a huge coffee bar, flanked by cases of deli sandwiches and pastries, fills the front of the store; the rack with a dozen kinds of beef jerky has been relegated to the back. The wall is painted in "grasslands," not off-white. Pendant lamps hang from faux tin ceilings, and the porcelain-tile floors are meant to look like wood. 
The store opened on Wednesday and, ceremonially at least, is the chain's 25,000th outlet worldwide. At the opening, waiters in tuxedos served doughnut centers and taquitos while a high school choir belted "Oh Thank Heaven," the paean to hot dogs, chips and Slurpees that was written last year for the company's 75th anniversary. The opening was not just a milestone for 7-Eleven Inc., whose stores had $33 billion in sales and a daily average of six million customers last year. It also was a chance to meditate on the chain-ification of cities -- and the evolution of the concept of convenience.
To Murray Forseter, editor and publisher of Chain Store Age, a trade publication, "it's a symbol of the nation of convenience we have become and actually the world has become; it's a symbol of the longevity of a concept."
To Jane Jacobs, the Toronto-based author of several books on cities and economics, "it's a symbol of stagnation; we don't want the same things on every corner, especially when it seems to be at the expense of having some really new ideas."
To Christina Callender, 20, a culinary school student who lives upstairs, it was a chance to get a free cherry-Coke Slurpee. "I grew up with a 7-Eleven down the street," she said between slurps.
"Who didn't?" asked her boyfriend, Jacob Rolfes.
The chain actually has 25,076 outlets worldwide -- its fast growth in Asia outpaced the grand-opening hoopla here -- compared with a total of 30,081 for McDonald's. In the United States, 7-Eleven has 5,775 stores, versus 15,646 for Subway, 13,531 for McDonald's and 5,609 for Blockbuster.
Such huge numbers are hardly surprising in a nation where chains account for 60 to 70 percent of all retail sales -- including restaurants but not cars. Chains have even made inroads in Manhattan, though 7-Eleven's plans for a Times Square store fell through last year.
"When we're used to one of these places, we don't want to go out of our way to find it," Wendy Liebman, president of WSL Strategic Retail, a consulting firm based in New York, said of the ubiquity of chains of all kinds. "We've come to know that we can guarantee that those companies in particular will provide a consistent product and offering. It short-circuits the discussion and the decision making."
Or, it short-circuits American culture, because the cookie-cutter interiors of many stores can make customers wonder whether they are in Chicago or Charlottesville.
"I don't want to sound too much like a crybaby or a whiner, but 7-Elevens are boring," said Eric Brown of the Center for a New American Dream, a nonprofit group that aims to counter the commercialism of culture. He added that he did not see the benefit of "counting on the sameness of McDonald's french fries or a Slurpee."
The chain began in Dallas in 1927 as the Southland Corporation, an ice company whose Tote'm stores offered eggs, milk and bread on the side. The stores' name changed in 1946, to pitch the novel notion of staying open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. The Slurpee, the company's icy carbonated signature, was introduced in 1966, and the Double Big Gulp, its 64-ounce cup for soft drinks, in 1988. Since 1991, when Southland emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, two Japanese companies -- Ito-Yokado and Seven-Eleven Japan -- have owned a majority interest in the company; its name was changed to 7-Eleven Inc. in 1999.
Today, nearly all 7-Elevens are open 24 hours a day. The chain says that it sells more cold bottled water, grilled hot dogs and money orders than any other American retailer, and that its customers visit an average of 17 times over four weeks, buying a total of a million cups of coffee a day and 11.6 million Slurpees a month.
MUCH of the chain's growth has been in Japan, which has 9,757 stores -- 77 per million people, far more than the 20 per million in the United States, but less than the 148 per million in Taiwan.
The frenetic growth in Asia, where convenience stores are more like pantries for city dwellers who are short on space, spurred the American strategy reflected in the River North store, one of 84 urban walk-up stores to open since 2000. The idea is to emphasize fresh food -- like a pair of hard-boiled eggs for 89 cents -- over packaged staples. "It's dashboard dining for the pedestrian, quite honestly," said Steve Hall, vice president for real estate and development. "In the urban environment we could probably have a store, literally, on every block."
The urban 7-Elevens are proliferating as the retail industry in general is focusing more on convenience. But while stores like Wal-Mart and Walgreens define convenience as ever-bigger stores with ever-expanding selection, 7-Eleven and other convenience-store chains are building smaller outlets with fewer products. These c-stores -- defined as places that are open at least 13 hours a day and sell, among other things, diapers, canned tuna, pet food, ketchup and toothpaste -- want people in and out, fast.
"We sell time, literally," said Jeff Lenard, spokesman for the National Association of Convenience Stores. "Whether you walk into a store or drive into a store, from the time you go in to the time you go out, is usually three to four minutes. Some of these other places offering one-stop shopping, you're probably looking at three to four minutes circling the parking lot."
At the new 7-Eleven in River North, Colin McQueen, a Londoner spending six weeks in Chicago, picked up The Financial Times on his way to work. Megan Ennessy, 24, marveled at the flavor shots -- cherry, lemon and vanilla -- at the new Slurpee machine.
"This amazes me: the Slurpees have come a long way," said Ms. Ennessy, who recalled biking to her suburban neighborhood 7-Eleven as a child but had not seen one since she moved downtown. "For me, Starbucks can be more of a treat. 7-Eleven can be an every-morning, every day kind of thing. Or night, really."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Tax Policy That Uses Economies Of Scales

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
AS most full-time residents of foreign vacation spots will tell you, Americans are fat. And, as statistics will tell you, we're getting fatter. Doctors and nutritionists have been encouraging us to slim down for years. But to solve a big part of this big problem of big people, we need economics.
 Wait a second, this sounds like economists' getting too big for their breeches again. Next they'll be telling us how to appreciate art or find a soul mate, right? Not quite. In many cases, the problem of obesity fits well into an economic model. 
 First of all, obesity often persists as a result of individual choice. It may result from a disease or an inherited condition. But most individuals have the power to affect their own weight through diet, exercise and other habits.
Second, obesity is easily observable. A few measurements are all it takes to place a person somewhere along the continuum from dangerously skinny to Brobdingnagian.
Third, an individual's obesity can affect many people. As a result, it becomes a societal issue as well as a medical problem.
Precisely identifying these effects can be difficult. At least one seems much more important than squeezed seats on airplanes, however. Obesity increases the risk of many medical problems. When someone has a heart attack, chances are either taxpayers or members of a private insurance plan will foot most of the bill. And, thanks to modern medicine, the obese elderly survive almost as long as their thinner counterparts.
Last month, a state assemblyman from Brooklyn suggested a tax on fatty foods to discourage their consumption. An economist might take exception to this plan, because the tax would punish even people who ate such foods in moderation. Of course, that has not stopped similar justifications for taxes on alcohol and cigarettes. Even if you have just one drink or cigarette a year, you still pay heavy "sin" taxes.
Two weeks ago, Kraft Foods decided to lower the fat content of some recipes and reduce the sizes of single-serving snacks. Again, this approach is slightly clumsy. Even if you're eating rice cakes, you'll gain weight if you eat enough of them. And though some Americans may be happy with a smaller packet of cookies, others may just buy two and finish them both. (Kraft said nothing about cutting the snacks' prices in line with the portions.)
Another kind of remedy might have more success. The problem is obesity, not fatty food or anything else that contributes to being overweight. So why not take aim at obesity directly?
Basic economics recommends taxing individual behaviors that hurt society. But taxing overweight people, perhaps by identifying them and then assessing them some social cost of obesity every year, sounds draconian and impractical.
A more palatable solution might be to collect a lump-sum tax from every American and put the proceeds into a reward pool. Each year, anyone who wanted to could go to an existing government office for a simple series of measurements. People who registered normal weights throughout the year would receive cash rewards from the pool -- much like a tax refund.
This system would still tax obesity, though it would not tax the heaviest people more than the merely rotund. Nor would it tax the middle-aged and disease-prone more than the roly-poly young. Nevertheless, the incentive to lose a few pounds might be quite powerful.
TO see why, consider just one cost of the overweight and obese population: the extra burden it imposes on the Medicare and Medicaid programs paid for by taxpayers. A study published in May by Eric Finkelstein and Ian Fiebelkorn of RTI International, a research group in North Carolina, and Guijing Wang of the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention put that figure at $40 billion to $50 billion a year. The average cost to society is about $250 a year for each of about 180 million heavy Americans.
There are about 300 million Americans in total, so setting the lump-sum tax at $100 a year would yield $30 billion for the reward pool -- enough to reward about 120 million Americans of normal weight with checks for $250.
Most likely, not everyone of normal weight would collect the reward. High-income thin people, for example, might be too busy for the weigh-in. These no-shows would allay the regressive nature of the lump-sum tax, as well as leave plenty of money to cover administrative costs.
Those who are not obese would be $150 richer on balance, while obese Americans would be out $100 -- a total difference of $250. And $250, though perhaps not foie gras, is not exactly chicken feed.

HEADLINE: Grand Theft Auto 

BYLINE:  By PHIL PATTON

 BODY:
CARS have all sorts of devices to protect them from being stolen. Car designs are just there for the taking.
 No shrill alarms warn passers-by to step away from a distinctive body shape. No global-positioning satellites track the perpetrators of roofline larceny and automatically alert the patent police. No late-night advertorials sell locking clubs to prevent wheel patterns from being purloined. 
 But on the road, drivers are more and more likely to do double takes on automotive double shapes. Doesn't that new Nissan Maxima look like a larger-scale Saturn Ion? Could the Kia Sorento be a Lexus RX 300 in disguise? Doesn't the face of the Nissan Z look like that of the Toyota Celica (and its taillamps like those of the Lexus SC 430)? Is that the new Bentley -- or the new Hyundai?
A few years ago, people complained that cars in general were beginning to look alike. But now cars in specific are looking more and more like other cars. Aerodynamics were once blamed for the melding of shapes into a common silhouette. Today, all designers confront the same detailed safety and economy standards, and they all work with the same "space packages" of dominant vehicle types, from minivans to S.U.V.'s to the blended vehicles known as crossovers.
But today's designers also communicate more with one another and move more often among companies and across continents. Many attended the same schools, notably the Art Center College in Pasadena, Calif.
In January, at the designers' party during the Detroit auto show, a Woodward Avenue club was packed with an all-star cast of designers from companies including Mitsubishi, Porsche, General Motors, Ford, BMW and Rolls-Royce. A bad seafood salad would have crippled the global auto industry.
Imitation pays the compliment not only of flattery, but of admiration. Jaguar's chief designer, Ian Callum, says certain seminal models have had such profound impact that they influence all the cars that come later. "The Porsche 911 was one, of course," he said. "The Audi TT was a watershed."
Today, admiration for the designs of Audis and Volkswagens has infected the looks of Nissans, Mitsubishis and even Fiats. Several leading designers now suggest that Nissan is setting the design standard, which would be a first for a Japanese company.
Success naturally breeds imitation. "Good artists copy; great artists steal," Picasso supposedly said, though the quotation itself has been swiped by others.
"Hommage" is Hollywood's polite word for this process. When Brian De Palma tumbled a baby carriage down a staircase in "The Untouchables," he paid homage to a similar scene in a 1925 Sergei Eisenstein film, "The Battleship Potemkin." But one man's hommage is another's petty theft. The Chrysler Crossfire's side vents pay homage to the car's corporate cousin, the Mercedes SL 500, but putting a Bentley rump on a Hyundai is something else.
Sometimes it is easy to see which of two similar cars came first. The Infiniti FX45 was already in production when its lines were shadowed by the Lexus HPX, a design study for a similar sport wagon. Since Lexus has not announced plans to build the HPX, it cannot be charged with theft, only intent. But in other cases, given the long progress of designs from sketch to metal, precedence is less clear. Did the Ion or the Maxima come first? (Another sedan with the counterfeit Ion roofline, the 2004 Mitsubishi Galant, isn't on sale yet.)
Some manufacturers use styling to suggest visually that their cars are the equal of more expensive models. Korean automakers seem especially unabashed in borrowing styling from more exclusive models, recalling the cloners of sunglasses who display dozens of styles with a sign that says, "Compare in price with Oakley." Or with Ray-Ban or Armani or Versace.
"Compare in price with Jaguar" may be the message of the Hyundai XG350's prominent grille, which also resembles those of Infinitis. The same car's rear suggests, "Compare with Bentley Arnage." The Hyundai Sonata's amoebic headlamps say, "Compare with Mercedes"; they look much like those of the C-Class.
Some styling features are borrowed because they send a more specific message. The signature of Jaguar's sporty R series cars is a black mesh grille that resembles medieval chain mail. When Cadillac wanted to signal that its new CTS-V was also a high-performance model, it added a mesh grille, too.
The Five-Hundred sedan in Ford's future looks like an Audi. No surprise, perhaps, since Ford's design chief, J Mays, was once in charge of Audi design. And the look is appropriate for the Five-Hundred's mission: to offer European luxury at an American price.
Many auto designs are ostensibly protected by design patents, which are far harder to enforce than technical ones. Mr. Mays's name is attached to several design patents, including one for the Concept One, precursor of the New Beetle.
"We get design patents on our work," said Joe Dehner, a Chrysler designer. "But that is more to protect against after-market manufacturers of replacement parts."
Last year, for the first time in memory , a company went to court to protect a design. DaimlerChrysler sued G.M. over similarities between grilles of Hummers and Jeeps, but failed to win in court. Chrysler also sent warning letters suggesting that grilles of the Lexus RX 300 and Kia Sportage were too close to Jeep's.
And G.M. sued a tiny Florida company, Avanti, over its design for a hulking S.U.V. that would revive the Studebaker nameplate. G.M. contends that the Studebaker looks too much like its Hummer H2. A hearing is scheduled for Aug. 18.
In his 1973 book "The Anxiety of Influence," Professor Harold Bloom of Yale suggests that poets start out trying to imitate older poets they admire. Those who have real talent fail at the effort, of course, and produce original works despite themselves. The idea may apply to car designers as well: sometimes, poetic license includes a license to steal.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Earnings Are Worse Without The Icing

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
CORPORATE earnings season got off to its official start last week, and the second-quarter results had better be good. If they are not, the big move in stocks of the last few months will have less footing than rational investors require. 
 But even if many companies report decent numbers, investors should not break out the Dom Perignon. Because the quality of earnings has declined so significantly among the nation's largest companies -- those in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- it is not hyperbolic to advise investors to view every profit report with suspicion. 
 David Bianco, accounting analyst at UBS in New York, said: "The quality of earnings for the S.& P. 500, from an accounting standpoint, is the worst it has been in more than a decade." And he has done the work to prove it.
The slide is largely the result of aggressive accounting practices in three areas, he said. First are so-called special charges, which companies say are one-time events from re-structurings or asset impairments, but which may actually include recurring operational costs that should be deducted from revenue. Second is the choice many companies have made not to subtract the costs of stock options from their results, and finally, there are those rosy pension assumptions -- inflating pension earnings or masking pension costs -- that improve corporate earnings.
Taken together, earnings at many companies are not what many investors think they are, Mr. Bianco said. As a result, these company shares sport a higher cost, in the form of a price-earnings ratio, than investors believe.
He analyzed results at each of the S.& P. 500 companies over the last 11 years, viewing earnings and accounting practices over an entire economic cycle. Then, he adjusted the companies' reported earnings for special charges, stock-option grants and overly rosy pension assumptions. What he found was that in 1991, the adjusted earnings were roughly 18 percent less than those the companies reported to shareholders: $15.91 a share versus $19.50 a share. 
Shifting to 2002, the difference grows vast: earnings adjusted for the funny stuff were 41 percent less than the profits reported to investors. 
So while investors may have thought that they were paying roughly 19 times the earnings of S.& P. companies to own the index last year, they were really paying almost 25 times profits after adjustments for the three items. 
At individual companies the numbers become even more troubling. Texas Instruments, which analysts expect to earn roughly 35 cents a share this year, would earn 10 cents a share if Mr. Bianco's adjustments were made. That increases its price-earnings ratio from 54 to 188, based on Friday's close. And at eBay, Mr. Bianco figures that while analysts forecast its profit at $1.46 a share, the figure would drop to 57 cents this year if adjusted by his method. That ramps up eBay's price-earnings ratio from 77 to 198.
ALTHOUGH Mr. Bianco can only estimate what the companies will report in special charges and the like, he has based his assumptions on historical norms.
"We've all been waiting for the day when people will be forced to acknowledge quality-of-earnings problems," Mr. Bianco said. "Some of it seems to be occurring." More companies are expensing the costs of stock options, and regulators are pushing companies to justify special charges. "If earnings are overstated because of these things," he said, and new rules force changes, "it's going to be more difficult for earnings to grow from these levels."
In other words, the great stock market bubble lives on.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 20, 2003

 CORRECTION:
The Market Watch column last Sunday, about the inflation of corporate profits through accounting practices related to pensions, stock options and one-time charges, misstated what the price-to-earnings ratio of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index would have been last year if the effects of such practices had been excluded. It was 31.4, not 25.
