LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: For Richer or Poorer, to Our Visa Card Limit 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BAYOT

 BODY:
The mermaid-shaped gown with the $4,200 price tag was the first purchase that Cynthia Davis, of Coral Springs, Fla., charged to her Visa card. 
 The tiered cake, the groom's tuxedo and gifts for the bridesmaids followed, putting Ms. Davis and her fiance, David Davis, in serious debt for the first time in their lives. 
 Two more credit cards paid for doves to be released after their vows and for a horse-drawn carriage to take them to their reception, where 340 guests would be waiting.
When the big day was over, the balance due was $12,000 -- a debt the couple struggled with for three years, through bouts of unemployment, until they separated in 2001. 
Wedding bills are weighing down couples and their parents long after the "I do's," and many have been forced to seek financial counseling as a result, according to credit counseling agencies. 
Young couples with modest incomes are having the most trouble repaying. Whether they celebrate lavishly or modestly, they are more likely than ever to pay for their weddings without help from their parents. And even when parents pay, what more and more people expect of nice weddings is increasingly more elaborate for both the richer and the poorer. And so, with debt do they start. 
Ms. Davis, now 23 and an administrator at an employment agency, has since entered credit counseling to help her manage her wedding debt.
"I hope everyone had a good time, because I'm still paying," Ms. Davis said, laughing, then quietly added, "really paying in a big way -- not only financially, but with my marriage."
Howard S. Dvorkin, the president of Consolidated Credit Counseling Services Inc., in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said, "Paying off these weddings is going to take a heck of a lot longer than the few hours the party lasted, maybe longer than the marriage lasts." He added, "Because there's the emotional aspect, people lose sight of the finances when they're getting married." 
Springboard Non-Profit Consumer Credit Management, based in Riverside, Calif., says that in 2002 close to 240 customers -- about 2 percent of its clients -- named wedding spending the primary source of their debts, more than double the figure for 2001. Springboard said that with the exception of poor budgeting every other cause of debt that clients cited at least as frequently was unavoidable, like unemployment or illness.
Consolidated Credit, one of the country's five largest accredited agencies, reports that so far this year 5.2 percent of its 6,000 new customers have cited wedding debt as a reason for seeking credit counseling, double the rate of wedding-related cases the company took on in 2000, just before the last recession began.
There has been no data collected on whether wedding debt is a factor in the increase in personal bankruptcies. But in some cases, such counseling is a step on the road toward bankruptcy.
For Mitchell and Sandra Crim of Bellevue, Wash., spending for their daughter Sarah's wedding day "was a matter of pride," said Mr. Crim, a customer service representative for Nintendo. "We did not want to appear cheap, or that we were incapable of giving her the wedding she wanted. And that's just part of the illusion." 
The 250-guest affair that the Crims held for their daughter in August 2001 saddled them with $4,000 of credit-card debt. The payments were a burden from the start, they said, and after Mrs. Crim's employer reduced her hours, the debt made even paying for groceries difficult. "And it was hurting our relationship," Mr. Crim said of his own marriage. "It's so difficult when the main focus of your existence is trying to find a way to pay these people," he said, referring to the creditors.
The Crims went for credit counseling this past February. They now make monthly payments under a plan that, Mr. Crim wryly notes, will take four to five years to pay the remaining bills from their daughter's big day. 
"If you have to buy something on credit, buy a house. Buy a car," he said. "Certainly do not buy a wedding."
But wedding planners across the country say that couples are, in fact, buying weddings on the installment plan. And although there are no numbers on how often brides and their families are borrowing, a recent survey of 1,400 bridal magazine readers found that last year 43 percent spent more on their weddings than they had budgeted.
The survey, from the Conde Nast Bridal Infobank, a research service for its wedding magazines, also found that the average wedding now costs $22,000, representing more than five months' worth of wages for amiddle-income family, according to data from the Census Bureau.
Yet after adjusting for inflation, that $22,000 represents only a 7 percent increase over the average cost of a wedding in 1990. Moreover, the average wedding consumes no more of a middle-income family's earnings than it did in 1990, suggesting that weddings are not necessarily less affordable than they were a decade ago. 
So why is wedding debt an issue now? 
For one thing, more couples are paying for their own weddings -- 27 percent last year versus 23 percent in 1997, according to the Bridal Infobank. And an additional 30 percent are paying at least part of the bill, up from 18 percent in 1997. Newlyweds typically earn less than their parents, and often already carry the burden of student loans. Many are also trying to save enough to make a down payment on a house. 
Wedding expectations, meanwhile, have far outgrown people's incomes, especially those in the low to moderate end, said Chrys Ingraham, an associate professor of sociology at Russell Sage College in Troy, N.Y., and author of "White Weddings," a book about America's fascination with weddings. Couples who years ago would have simply married at City Hall are now "emulating what they believe to be an upper-class model," Ms. Ingraham said. "There is this notion that the big wedding is a good thing for everybody."
Pamela J. Smock, a sociologist at the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan, last year interviewed about 120 people who were living with their romantic partners and earning low to moderate incomes. She said she found that the inability to pay for "a real wedding" was keeping a fifth of them from marrying. 
"The perceived cost of the wedding -- what we as a culture have now decided is the standard for a wedding -- is very powerful," Ms. Smock said.
A sluggish economy is also making wedding debt more of a problem. Only two months after Stacey and Justin Blair amassed $20,000 in credit card debt to pay for their May 2001 wedding, Mr. Blair was laid off from his job as a laboratory technician. Ms. Blair said that because of their wedding debt, the couple had to move into her aunt's house to save on rent.
They also parted with their two leased cars in favor of sharing a used car, and they enlisted a financial planner to monitor their spending, even submitting their credit card statements for review each month. "Everything was just a mess," Ms. Blair said. Still, she considers the wedding well worth it: "It was such a fun day, I didn't care how much we put on our credit cards."
But the impact of wedding debt goes beyond finances. During the first five years of marriage, the most common and intense source of conflict among couples under the age of 30 is debt brought into marriage, according to a large national study conducted in 1999 by the Center for Marriage and Family at Creighton University in Omaha. Among all of the nearly 800 spouses surveyed, regardless of age, it was the third-most-troubling issue, behind time management and sexual issues.
For Trisha Betts, a 26-year-old office manager from Houston, repaying her $6,000 wedding loan meant spending more than three years scrimping and living with the occasional suspension of telephone service. It meant frequent arguments with her husband. The two divorced on Feb. 13. "If we didn't have any debt, things would have been different," Ms. Betts said.
At the same time, Ms. Betts shares the opinion of many marriage therapists that financial stress is commonplace in married life. 
Michael G. Lawler, the director of the Center forMarriage and Family, said, "It's the United States of America, after all, and there's going to be some sort of debt." He added, "The question is what strategies do you have, together, to deal with the debt?" 
Douglas and Jacqueline Weaver, who live in Rockmart, Ga., spent more than a decade dealing with the $5,500 or so in credit card debt that they incurred for their wedding in 1992, when they were barely 21. 
They finished repaying it last month, after nearly five years in a debt management program.
Ms. Weaver said the experience has taught them patience: whether that meant waiting to use their single car while the other was out, or saving enough to buy a second car, or taking day trips instead of having out-of-town vacations, or chipping away at debt keeping them from buying a house. Mostly, Ms. Weaver said, the debt taught them to have patience with each other.
Last week, the Weavers took their two sons on a trip to the Smoky Mountains for the family's first big vacation since a honeymoon trip to Orlando, Fla. 
"We've been married for 11 years, and we just are finally seeing light," Ms. Weaver said happily.
And when they returned home on Friday night, it was to their own house, which they bought last year.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
Art on Main Street
Westport has invited 128 artists from 18 states and Canada to exhibit their juried work in the town's 30th annual Fine Arts Festival on Saturday from 9 to 7:30 and Sunday from 9 to 6. Main Street will be closed to traffic to accommodate the event.
 Artists from many states, including California, Alabama, Florida, New England, Ohio, Oregon and Virginia will be displaying oils, watercolors, pastels, sculpture and etchings. There will also be plenty of entertainment, including the Mystic Paper Beasts, Giacomo Gates and Friends, the Wiggins Sisters, the Jimmy Kelly Band, Dan Bonis and Friends. Cafe Musette will feature Cynthia McCorkindale, a jazz song stylist and pianist, Larry Urbon on guitar, and Jeff Eyrick on bass on stage almost continuously. 
 Part of the proceeds from an art auction scheduled on Wednesday from 7 to 10 p.m. will help support the Hole in the Wall Gang camp for seriously ill youngsters. 

Books Around the Corner
Festival-goers have another reason to be in Westport on Saturday, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday as well, when the library, across the Post Road from Main Street, holds its summer book sale. 
Sci-fi devotees will head for the 67 Star Trek video tapes, offered as a collection until 11 a.m. Saturday; and thousands of books will be available on sports, games, homes, gardens, wine, food, business, computers, religion, philosophy, adult and children's paperbacks and hard covers ranging from 50 cents up. Videos, CD's, audio and music cassettes, books-on-tape and LP albums should turn up something for almost everyone. 
Hours on Saturday and Sunday are 9 to 5, Monday is half-price day from 9 to 9, Tuesday everything is free from 9 to whenever, with cash contributions welcome. Information: (203)227-8411.

Blooming Roxbury
 Eight private gardens will be opened to the public, some for the first time, in Roxbury. They include Richard Daniel Daylily Gardens in peak bloom, the writer Tovah Martin's cottage garden of heirloom plants, wildflowers and hollyhocks, and the organic vegetable farm owned by David Blyn and Laura McKinney. 
Visitors will be welcome from 1 p.m. Saturday until 6:30, when they will convene at the library, 23 South Street, for a champagne reception until 7:30. Tickets with self-guiding maps for $50 in advance and $65 on Saturday may be picked up at Minor Memorial Library, 23 South Street, whose Contemplation Garden is the beneficiary of the event.
Other properties are Peter Wooster's quarter-acre garden; Michael and Zena Wiener's Ravenrock, at the top of a cliff overlooking a bamboo forest, sculptures, a Japanese stroll garden and barberry parterre; the garden of Arthur Carter, publisher of The New York Observer and former publisher of The Litchfield County Times, who has positioned his own sculptures and his studio in a meadow by a rushing stream; Riverbank Farm, a certified organic garden; Hillside Garden's rose parterres, water and stone features in the European tradition; and the Muszala family's formal garden terraces that surround their historic home. Information: (860) 350-2181.

Uncle Sam in Sherman
 James Montgomery Flagg's famous 1917 poster of Uncle Sam pointing a finger at the viewer, with the caption "I Want YOU for U.S. Army," was the catalyst for the Sherman Library's new exhibition called "Uncle Sam in Propaganda -- WWI to Gulf War II."
According to the library, the Flagg poster was designed to "give the masses a sense of personal involvement in the 'Good War' the virtues of self sacrifice and participation." Other prominent commercial artists of the time like Edward Penfield and J.C. Leyendecker created similarly rousing art for the government
By the time World War II rolled around, artists including Flagg, Norman Rockwell, N.C. Wyeth and Ben Shahn were giving Uncle Sam a more militaristic aspect, a warrior opposing an evil foe, and an icon for many causes including espionage and the economy. 
Seymour Chwast's 1967 anti-war caricature poster of Uncle Sam, "End Bad Breath," shows a wild-eyed uncle in his stars and stripes top hat, with a flight of bomb-dropping planes flying over houses in his gaping mouth. 
The library, on Route 39 in Sherman's town center, is open Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, 11 to 6; Thursday, 11 to 7, and Saturday, 10 to 4. Information: (860)354-2455. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: If You Build It, They Will Come? 

BYLINE:  By TERRY GOLWAY

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
RICK CERONE, son of Newark and a New Jersey baseball legend, has no answers.
 Sitting behind a desk 18 stories above Broad Street here, in a building no more than 200 yards from a baseball stadium born of his imagination and passion, the 48-year-old former Yankee catcher is trying to explain why so few people are coming to watch the team he revived, the Newark Bears. 
 "I'll be honest with you, I thought we'd be selling out the stadium every night," Mr. Cerone said in a recent interview, jerking his head to the left. The ballpark -- Bears and Eagles Riverfront Stadium, named for the old Bears and the Eagles, which played in the Negro League -- is somewhere over his left shoulder, between Broad Street and Route 21. It is early in the morning in Newark, so the grandstands are empty. 
 The trouble is, when game time arrives those grandstands remain painfully vacant.
 Of course, there are reasons for the rows of empty stands: fear of traipsing through the darkened streets of Newark late at night, and so many other sports and entertainment venues in the New York area. But the fact that residents of North Jersey will not venture into the heart of the state's largest city to watch a ballgame on a summer's night is a cautionary tale for those who want the Nets and the Devils to abandon the Meadowlands for a new sports arena in Newark. 
 "With the Bears, we have a great product," Mr. Cerone said. "We've had big-name players like Rickey Henderson. We've won the league championship and should have won another, and we have great sponsor support. The only thing missing in Newark are the bodies. I don't know why."
 For emphasis, he repeated himself, twice: "I don't know why. I don't know why." 
 This year marks the fifth season in the life of the stadium, which opened -- or half-opened, since it was not quite finished when the gates opened in 1999 -- at a cost to Essex County taxpayers of $34 million.
 Despite outsized publicity, including articles in national magazines and coverage on ESPN, this year the Bears' have been drawing only about 3,000 at each game through early July, about half the stadium's capacity -- even with the presence of one of baseball's greatest leadoff hitters, Mr. Henderson, who joined the Bears this year in an effort to work his way back into the major leagues at age 44.
 Yet other minor league teams in New Jersey are doing better, and in some cases spectacularly well. The Trenton Thunder, a Double A team affiliated with the Yankees (and formerly, the Boston Red Sox), have attracted four million fans since the team's founding in 1993.
 The Lakewood Blueclaws, a Single A affiliate of the Philadelphia Phillies, regularly draw 6,000 or more. Among teams like the Bears, which play in the independent minor leagues -- those not affiliated with Major League baseball -- the Somerset Patriots average about 5,000 fans at each home game, and the Camden Riversharks, playing in a city that has replaced Newark as a symbol of New Jersey's urban decay, draw close to 4,000 a game. 
 Going into this year, the Bears had drawn about 800,000 people since the stadium opened in mid-season in 1999. Attendance declined from a high of 243,255 in 2001 to 208,634 last year. 
 What is worse, the Bears' official attendance figures, based on ticket sales, do not always square with actual attendance. On the night of June 30, for example, a warm, pleasant evening with the Bears playing host to the Pennsylvania Road Warriors, the announced crowd of 3,900 seemed more like 1,000, maybe 1,500.
 The crowd at a July 4 matinee against the Camden Riversharks, announced at 2,281, seemed a good deal less than 1,000. There were yawning gaps in the box seats ($9per seat), and only a few dozen people were scattered throughout the bleachers ($7) down the right field and left field lines.
 Last September, when the Bears won the championship of the independent Atlantic League, the announced crowd was disappointing enough at 2,014. But by all accounts, including Mr. Cerone's, only about 800 to 1,000 people were actually on hand to cheer Newark's first professional baseball championship since the days of the old Newark Bears, the celebrated and long-gone Yankee minor league team that once featured a catcher from St. Louis named Lawrence Berra.
 A few months after that bittersweet day in September, Mr. Cerone sold half his interest in the team for what he described only as "less than market value," though the team is worth an estimated at $3 million.
 Mr. Cerone -- who grew up in the North Ward in the shadow of the Sacred Heart Cathedral -- was exhausted, he admitted, and frustrated, too.
 "My vision was to help bring people back to Newark, which the stadium has done," he said. "But what I didn't calculate was the competition for the entertainment dollar in North Jersey. Still, there are millions of people within a 15-mile radius of the ballpark. I don't know, I don't have the answer. I got a little tired."
 His new partner is Steve Kalafer, the 53-year-old owner of an automobile dealership, Flemington Car and Truck County, who lives in Annandale, Hunterdon County. Mr. Kalafer, who grew up in North Caldwell, is also a documentary film producer, real estate developer and owner of the highly successful Somerset Patriots, an Atlantic League team that plays in Commerce Bank Stadium in Bridgewater. 
 The Bears essentially are Mr. Kalafer's now, and he recently named Marc Berson of Millburn, a friend and business partner, as the team's chairman. He said that while his ownership stake is 50 percent, he is 100 percent responsible for the team's daily operations. 
In fact, Mr. Cerone conceded that he soon may sell 45 percent of his remaining 50 percent share of the Bears, though he would not disclose to whom. But even if he did, he said, he would continue to play an active role as the team's founder and best-known cheerleader. 
 "That will never change, whether I own 50 percent, as I do now, or 5 percent, as I might in the future," he said.
 In any case, writing Mr. Cerone out of the team's life would seem to be premature. Encased in glass outside the Bears' executive offices is Mr. Cerone's uniform from his days as an All-American catcher at Seton Hall University in neighboring South Orange, where he starred from 1973 to 1975. Lining a corridor near the ballpark's press box are more than a half-dozen plaques presented to Mr. Cerone in recent years. And a Bears' fan in search of a mixed drink and shade is welcome to visit "Rick's Upper Deck" on the first base side of the stadium. 
 Mr. Kalafer, while not about to rewrite history, is clearly looking to break with the team's recent frustrations. Sitting in the dugout of Commerce Bank Stadium and watching rain threaten a sellout between his Patriots and the Atlantic City Surf, Mr. Kalafer said he was committed to the Bears and to Newark. 
 "This is a building year," he said of the 2003 season. "During the next two years, we will be reintroducing the Newark Bears to the Essex County community and to the city of Newark."
 It takes two to become reacquainted, however, and even some Bears' fans wonder if the relationship will work out. Those concerns range from the prosaic -- a lack of parking and the abandoned buildings, razor wire and security gatesthat define the streetscape near the stadium -- to the cosmic, like the reasonable question: Is the much-hailed Newark renassiance more hype than substance? 
 As seen through Mayor Sharpe James's prism, the problem with the Bears would seem to be largely racial -- even though minorities make up almost the entire team. "To the best of my knowledge," Mr. James said last week, "there has never been any visible or known minority personnel within the organization involved in significant administrative roles." 
 From a business standpoint, the mayor said he thought the "organization needs to reevaluate its marketing strategy and look at this city's demographics."
 "We have a large senior presence here, many of whom remember when minor league baseball in Newark was king," he said. "Why isn't more outreach done to them? It is not an impossibility to fill those seats, but it does help to have a comprehensive strategy." 
 Based on the Bears' attendance problems, it is clear that the economic revival of Newark will require more than a new stadium. But the city's defenders point to the notable success of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, just down Broad Street. 
 Jeff Norman, spokesman for NJPAC, said the concert hall, which opened in the fall of 1997, has drawn 3.2 million people in its six seasons of operation. And in the 2001-2002 season, Mr. Norman added, it sold more than 18,000 subscriptions. 
 Then again, the comparison is not entirely fair, since NJPAC had nearly 400 dates in the 2001-2002 season, compared with the Bears' 72 home games, and a full house in Prudential Hall is 2,750 -- which is somewhat less than the Bears' average attendance this year.
 Still, Mr. Kalafer cited the success of NJPAC as proof that suburbanites will venture into Newark for the right experience. 
 "Is Newark so different from other urban areas that have been able to build a relationship with a minor league team," he asked -- his voice suggesting that he believed the correct answer was no, Newark was not different from, say, Camden.
 Perhaps the problem is something else. 
 "Does there need to be a structural change between the Bears and the city of Newark, Essex County, the corporate community?, Mr. Kalafer asked. "The answer is yes."
 Many fans -- white, black, Hispanic, Asian, urban and suburban -- would agree that change of some sort is desperately needed. What they do not necessarily agree on is the problem, other than pointing out that minor league baseball is now a statewide industry. Eight teams dot the New Jersey map, and all have come into existence since 1993. One team, the New Jersey Jackals of the Northeastern League, plays in Little Falls, plays just a few miles from Newark.
 During the first few soggy weeks of the 2003 season, the two teams occasionally played on the same night, diluting each other's market. Put the two teams' attendance together, and you would have about 5,000 fans a night in one of the two parks.
"If you plot out the locations of minor league baseball on a map of New Jersey, Newark and the Jackals are the only two teams that share what I could consider a common market," said Mark Magyar of the Public Policy Center of New Jersey.
 Sitting in a box seat near home plate in late June, Wayne Johnson of Hillside complained that concession prices, not a market glut, keeps many Newark residents away. With his 5-year-old son, Wayne Johnson Jr., at his side and wielding a miniature Bears bat, Mr. Johnson noted that he had spent $5.50 for two hot dogs. 
 "That's a lot of money for people in Newark," he said. On the other hand, it is not as steep as Major League prices. At Yankee Stadium, for instance, a hot dog costs $4.
 Others wonder whether any sports venture in New Jersey can succeed, pointing to the empty seats in Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands, home to the New Jersey Devils hockey team and current owners of the Stanley Cup and the New Jersey Nets, two-time finalists in the National Basketball Association. Nor does Seton Hall University or Rutgers University draws huge crowds for their big-time collegiate schedules.
 "I just don't think New Jersey is a great sports area," said Drew Bauman, a lawyer from Maplewood and an old-fashioned fan who still studies box scores. 
 "Let's face it," Mr. Bauman added, "I don't think there would be much weeping if the Devils and Nets left the state. There isn't a strong allegience to New Jersey teams, which is why the Nets and Devils don't sell out, even for playoff games. As for the Bears, their problem is Newark's problem: People don't want to go there."
 Even those who do go -- and Mr. Bauman is a regular, despite his gloomy view -- seem aware that they are a lonely few. On July 4, Corey Winograd drove his two boys, 7-year-old Jack and 4-year-old Eric, from their home in Livingston to the Orange station on New Jersey Transit's Morris and Essex line. From there, they took a Hoboken-bound train to Broad Street station, less than a five-minute walk from the stadium. 
 The unusual route was prompted not by fear of parking in Newark, but by nostalgia. "Taking a train to a minor league game on July 4 -- that's Americana," Mr. Winograd explained. 
 Asked why there weren't more people sharing his red, white and blue dream, he pointed to a gutted skeleton once known as the Lincoln Motel, one of the ballpark's less-attractive neighbors. "Who wants to come here?" he asked.
 Of course, as dreadful as the shell of the Lincoln Motel is, Joseph DiVincenzo, the Essex County executive, has met with Mr. Kalafer to discuss not only the county's role in rehabilitating the surrounding area, but also to talk economics. The Essex County Improvement Authority, an arm of the county government, issued the bonds to build the ballpark and reserved for the county the right to sell the stadium's 20 skyboxes and its naming rights. Five seasons later, the boxes remain unsold, and Mr. DiVincenzo says he is now willing to return those rights to the team.
 "We're refining the lease because there are things we would not be doing," he said. 
 In return for their use of the stadium, the Bears give the county $1 for every ticket sold and a quarter of the revenue from the concessions. In addition, the county runs the limited parking concession, collecting $5 per car. Debt service on the bonds that financed the ballpark runs $1.6 million a year.
 Mr. DiVincenzo makes a distinction between the stadium and the Bears, contending that the ballpark has been a success even if the Bears are having a hard time keeping it half-filled.
 "The stadium is not just for baseball," he said. "It is for multiple purposes, and it has been successful for the community activities that take place there. We have 300,000 people who come there every year for baseball or other activities, like the Greater Newark Baseball Tournament, which used to be in Verona. We also have concerts there."
 Still, he said he understood that changes had to be made and that the city and the countywould have to work closely with Mr. Kalafer to make the neighborhood more welcoming and convenient. For instance, he said the music store would come down, and a parking deck would be built. 
 Because while the Bears may be a minor league outfit, they share a problem with major league in cities: Where to put the cars? Colleen McDonald of West Orange said she enjoyed going to Bears games with her 8-year-old son Patrick a few times a year, though she would come more often if the parking was more convenient.
 Despite the obvious concerns, fans at the stadium expressed few, if any, complaints about the team or the facility itself. The romance of minor league baseball -- the enthusiasm on the field and the child-friendly outreach in the grandstands -- is very much alive in Newark. 
 For now, Mr. Kalafer seems convinced he can remove whatever obstacles stand between his team and a warm embrace by the surrounding community that translates into ticket sales and fan loyalty over the next two years as he tries to rebuild the Bears in the mold of his Somerset Patriots. 
 As for Mr. Cerone, whose determination stood him in good stead during his 18 seasons in the Major Leagues, he is already thinking about yet another sports venue.
 "You know," he said, his eyes looking away, "I think Newark should get a new arena for the Nets and Devils. But if we don't, I'd love to talk to somebody about building a smaller arena, with 7,000 seats. You look around the country -- these smaller arenas are making a ton of money. That's an idea I'd be willing to put my efforts into."

HEADLINE: In the Shadow of the Stadium, an Eyesore 

BYLINE:  By TERRY GOLWAY

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
DON'T talk to Steve Kalafer, the new owner of the Newark Bears, about the Lincoln Motel, which sits conspicuously in the shadow of Bears and Eagles Riverfront Stadium. 
 The decrepit shell of a motel that once featured a kitschy picture of Lincoln has been closed for years, though to describe it as shuttered would be wrong, since many of walls are missing from the litter-strewn building that once sheltered homeless people. 
 For years, the motel -- situated along stretch of town hard by Interstate 280 -- was known for its short stays and constant mentions in police reports. 
 The building that became the Lincoln was erected in 1966 as a Holiday Inn. But when the city's economy faltered after the race riots in 1967, travelers began to stay at the hotels springing up at Newark International Airport, and the Lincoln fell into disrepair. It had closed by the time Miles P. Berger, a developer and currently a leading ally of Mayor Sharpe James, bought it in 1976 for the rock-bottom price of $500,000. Mr. Berger later bought several other hotels in the city and converted them for use by welfare recipients, earning him millions in government social service contracts.
 In 1999, with the stadium going up not more than 1,000 feet from the motel's door and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center just around the corner, Mr. Berger said he believed the time was right to invest in Newark's tourist trade. His plan was to gut the structure, install new furnishings, revive the swimming pool, restore the second-floor ballroom and reopen as a franchise. Though he declined to be specific about the timing, he said in June 1999 that it would happen within the next five months and that "the end is near." 
 Four years later, however, the end does not seem any nearer. Fenced in and with its 200 tiny rooms exposed, the motel runs the length of the left field grandstands. Rail commuters who pass through the Broad Street station are left to ponder the imagery of a crisp new taxpayer-built baseball stadium side by side with the shell of a onetime crime-ridden homeless shelter.
 "The fact that the Lincoln Motel is there, half-demolished, is disgraceful and inexcusable," Mr. Kalafer said. 
 Or as Corey Winograd of Livingston, who took his two young sons to a Bears game on July 4, put it, "For a fan to see that, what message is that giving of Newark?"
 Visions of a gleaming new hotel, along with economic development on Broad Street and the Passaic River, now seem relegated to late-90's happy talk. Adjacent to the park are not the hoped-for sports bars and restaurants, but gated storefronts, an abandoned music store, a check-cashing store and a beauty supply shop advertising 100 percent synthetic and human hair. 
 The music store is scheduled for demolition, said Joseph DiVincenzo, the Essex County executive. But action on razing the Lincoln Motel has been delayed because of reconstruction of Route 21, just beyond the stadium's left field fence. To Mr. Kalafer, that is no excuse. "Nobody has attempted to secure the visual appearance of the property," he said. "Many times you can close a site like that with plywood and invite schools to decorate it with artwork. That would take an eyesore and turn it into something neutral."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
Science Fiction, A Scary Proposition

BYLINE:  By LEWIS BEALE

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
GORDON VAN GELDER'S business is in the black these days, but that doesn't mean he is rolling in money. Far from it. Monthly profits can usually be measured in the three-figure range for Mr. Van Gelder, who is the owner, publisher and editor of a venerable but struggling science fiction monthly that specializes in short stories.
 "I never got into this thinking I was going to get rich," Mr. Van Gelder, 36, said from his cluttered apartment here, which serves as home and intergalactic headquarters for The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction, the 54-year-old magazine he bought three years ago. 
 "I bought the magazine because it was the only way I could be sure I could continue editing it," said Mr. Van Gelder, a native of Harrington Park who was editor of the magazine for four years before acquiring it. "I do the business end of it just so I can be able to play with the magazine and find new writers. That's the best part of it." 
 Business was not Mr. Van Gelder's original career path. A science fiction fan since childhood, he majored in creative writing at Princeton, then worked for St. Martin's Press for more than a decade, editing science fiction, mystery and pop culture titles. Because St. Martin's published several story collections culled from Fantasy and Science Fiction, Mr. Van Gelder became friendly with Ed Ferman, then publisher of the magazine. Mr. Ferman was about to retire and asked Mr. Van Gelder to consider editing the publication. Mr. Van Gelder said yes, juggled his responsibilities at St. Martin's and the magazine for the next several years and then bought the magazine in October 2000 for less than $100,000.
 What Mr. Van Gelder acquired was a well-known niche publication struggling to maintain readership in a difficult market. Founded in 1949, Fantasy and Science Fiction is the second longest-running science fiction magazine in the country. (In first place is Analog, founded in 1930 as Astounding Science Fiction.)
 It has published such writers as Ray Bradbury, Isaac Asimov, Walter Moseley and Kurt Vonnegut Jr. It was also the original publisher of Stephen King's "The Dark Tower" and the short story "Flowers for Algernon," which became the 1968 Oscar-winning film "Charly."
 But even though science fiction remains a popular genre read by millions of fans, its short-story category has fallen on hard times. That is a major reason the magazine's circulation has fallen to around 29,000 from 35,000 monthly (15,000 from newsstand sales) since Mr. Van Gelder took over the publication. 
 "A lot of the older readers are dying off, and we're not getting enough new subscribers," he said. "Fiction magazines as a whole have been dying since television came up. Many readers, when they take time to read something, want a big long book they can get lost in. They don't want it to be over in 30 pages, and then make the commitment again to something new."
 Still, the magazine remains a must-read for its core audience, which Mr. Van Gelder says is predominantly male, middle-class, college-educated and over 40. And it continues to attract tyro writers who hope to break into the field -- the magazine receives 500 to 700 submissions a month, of which only 1 percent make it into print, he said.
 The magazine pays authors 5 to 8 cents a word, which means that even a superstar author like Joyce Carol Oates, who recently appeared in the magazine's pages, earns less than $1,000 a story. So what's in it for them?
 "Not much," said Mr. Van Gelder, "which is why most agents don't even represent short fiction anymore. Their commissions are too low to make it worth their time. But for the writers, it's what they love doing. Some will write short stories to try out an idea they want to adapt for a novel. Stephen King loves the short-story form; he started out writing for us and for men's magazines."
 In this kind of financial atmosphere, economies of scale are important. Mr. Van Gelder's bare-bones staff is mostly freelancers who work part time. He takes a salary that he says is less than $50,000 a year, similar to what he was making at St. Martin's. The magazine's monthly editorial budget rarely tops $5,000, and printing costs are $10,000 per issue. Full-page ads run about $900, and the back cover, the only full-color advertisement in the publication, costs $2,200. Mr. Van Gelder estimates that he needs to sell 10 ads an issue to pay his printing bill but usually sells only about half that number.
 When it came to business, Mr. Van Gelder had to unlearn a lot of things he knew about book publishing that simply did not apply in the magazine world.
 "In book publishing," he said, "I could look at a book and say, 'This book you can estimate X number of copies sold,' and you'd probably want X plus 1,000 for your firstprinting, and if that sells out, you go back and reprint. With magazines you don't have returns, so you try to pare down your print run to precisely the right level, because in a month nobody wants the issue."
 Mr. Van Gelder's learning curve also involved subscription matters. He knew nothing about the subscription renewal process, how to seek new readers (he now does a direct-mail promotion every year) or what to say to angry subscribers -- like the Canadian sci fi fans who recently canceled their subscriptions after they realized the mail between the two countries was so slow that the magazine appeared on newsstands weeks before they got their issues.
 At least the magazine isn't bothered by a lot of competition. Mr. Van Gelder says that "you can pretty much count on one hand" the number of publications, including Analog, Realms of Fantasy and Asimov's Science Fiction, that vie with his on the newsstands, and that "the real competition is to get the best writers to write short fiction at all." Nor is he particularly concerned that he works in what many people consider a marginalized literary genre.
 "If science fiction isn't marginalized, it's doing something wrong," he said. "The form is so amorphous, I think it's fundamentally more threatening, more radical, that a lot of people who turn to fiction for comfort reading are inherently going to be put off by it. It's much more difficult than fantasy, which vastly outsells science fiction in book form."
 Which is to say that as far as the owner of Fantasy and Science Fiction is concerned, he's fighting the good fight: keeping the publication alive, publishing the best fiction he can find, developing new authors. He hopes to inject some much-needed capital into the business with two story collections culled from the magazine's pages, the first to be issued by the independent publisher Four Walls Eight Windows. And he has contingency plans, like cutting back on the frequency of publication, to keep the magazine alive in case falling subscriptions threaten its existence. 
 "The only way to make it work," he said, "is to go out there and hustle and keep hustling and just don't let up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gordon Van Gelder is the owner, publisher and editor of The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction in Hoboken, the second longest-running science fiction magazine in the country. He said he bought the 54-year-old magazine three years ago "because it was the only way I could be sure I could continue editing it." (Timothy Ivy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Hold Your Applause For the Budget Show

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE 

 BODY:
So, was the fight over arts financing just a shadow play after all? 
 It sure seemed that way back in April, when Governor McGreevey held a number of ostentatiously private meetings with groups representing various key beneficiaries of state funds, particularly in the arts. The meetings were private only in the sense that they were held behind closed doors. But they were public in the sense that the participants were all but ushered into the arms of waiting reporters to describe the grim news the governor had delivered: under the duress of budget woes, state financing of the arts would go to zero, from $18 million. 
 In the convoluted paths of politics, the idea was to so alarm a key constituency, a vocal, organized and politically connected constituency, that its members would fan out and do the governor's heavy lifting for him, requesting, nay demanding, a full restoration of the arts money by whatever means it took.
 Jeffrey Woodward, managing director of the McCarter Theater Center and chairman of Art Pride New Jersey, an advocacy group, was at the meetings. "The governor, in his first meeting with us, when he announced what he wanted to do, said, 'You should scream bloody murder,"' Mr. Woodward recalled in an interview. "Those were his words, and we did."
 In other words, the governor was putting on a bit of theater of his own, expressing outrage at the cuts the budget crisis was forcing him to perform, and urging his friends to protest.
 But was it theater of the real, or a sham? The guessing here back then was that it was a fix, that the governor would use the outcry to reluctantly enact the new taxes he wanted all along so as to preserve a vital part of the state's cultural life. But the people who lived through those days say that outcome was far from a certain.
 "I don't think it was a given that we were going to get it restored," Mr. Woodward said. "If you look around the country, in states like Florida and Colorado and others, you'll find any number of places where the arts have been cut to nothing because of budget problems."
 Joe Roberts, the Assembly majority leader, said the same.
 "You probably could have concluded that it would not have been zeroed out, $18 million to zero, and there certainly was an element of the governor trying to mobilize the arts community to appeal to the Legislature," Mr. Roberts said in an interview. "He admitted as much. But even after the marches on Trenton and a lot of focus on this issue," he went on, Mr. McGreevey considered easing the cut, spending no more than $9 million on the arts. In fact, Mr. Roberts said, the $9 million that the governor was contemplating would have been shared by arts groups as well as historical organizations that now receive about $10 million from the state. 
 Budget time is always the season of marches on Trenton, but the arts people wouldn't be arts people if they didn't know how to put on a show. Tony Randall, Eric Bogosian and other marquee names guaranteed plenty of news coverage, and you could hardly attend the theater, go to an opening or visit a museum in New Jersey all spring without hearing or reading an appeal to call your legislator and demand more money for the arts.
 In the end, the arts got what they wanted and more: a dedicated piece of the new state hotel and motel tax that restores their money and that will increase next year as the tax kicks in. With their financing restored and a secure line in the budget, at least until a more powerful constituency poaches it, Mr. Woodward and the rest of the arts community are too relieved and too grateful to say anything bad about the governor's budget brinkmanship.
 "The last five months have been incredibly disruptive in cultural institutions, both in the time needed to restore funding and the distractions of not knowing what we were going to receive," Mr. Woodward said. "So I can't say that it been an easy period of time." 
 "But that said," he added, "I understand this has been a tough time economically, and I hope with the tax in place, things will be easier next year."

HEADLINE: Judge Orders Lower Flow On the Missouri 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
A federal judge today ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to consider environmental issues more fully when it makes decisions about water flow for the Missouri River that could threaten the region's most endangered wildlife. 
 The judge, Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court here, granted an injunction sought by several environmental groups that have filed a lawsuit against the corps, which manages the river's dam and reservoir system. The groups say high water flows in parts of the river in the summer cause nesting and breeding problems for at least two species of birds and one type of fish. 
 Under federal law, the corps' actions cannot jeopardize endangered or threatened wildlife. The environmental groups want the plan to include a component that will require low flows in the summer. Judge Kessler's injunction prohibits the corps from putting a plan into effect without such a component.
Tim Searchinger, a lawyer for Environmental Defense, one of the plaintiffs in the case, described the court order as a "prelude" to the river operating in a more natural state. Beginning Tuesday, Mr. Searchinger said, the corps will be required to lower water flows on the river for six weeks.
He acknowledged that low water levels would probably have a negative economic effect, especially on barges on the Missouri. The effects might be especially significant in Nebraska and Missouri, and may include higher electrical costs. 
Carol Sanders, a spokeswoman for the Army Corps of Engineers, said the case was "another example of the conflicts that we face in the future regarding the nation's scarce water resources." 
Ms. Sanders added, "In the corps's operation in the Missouri, we've always tried to address the needs of wildlife and our navigation and reservoir users, and of course to comply with the law."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: In Manhattan by the End of 2005; 
14 New Hotels Are Planned

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The sag in tourism notwithstanding, developers are planning to establish 14 new hotels in Manhattan by the end of 2005 that will add 2,338 rooms to the 63,600 currently available, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm.
 Five of the new hotels will be limited-service operations flying such flags as Doubletree and Hampton Inn in contrast to the high-end boutique and large-scale hotels that were most common in recent years, according to the report. 
 In the last five years, 53 hotels opened or were extensively refurbished in Manhattan. Of these, 17 were boutiques, with planned rates as much as $400 a night, and five were large-scale, with more than 500 guest rooms.
"Continued interest in building hotels in Manhattan reflects the optimism of market participants and the sustained faith in the New York City economy," said Sean Hennessey, director of the firm's hospitality and leisure practice in the metropolitan area.
Hotel developers are also seeking locations outside the Midtown and Downtown business cores, according to the report. A 115-room hotel to be called Surface is being built at 107 Rivington Street on the Lower East Side and is scheduled to open later this year. And on the Upper East Side, a Courtyard by Marriott, with 226 rooms, is planned for East 92nd Street. JOHN HOLUSHA

HEADLINE: Investing; 
In DevelopingCountries, Prices May Be Right

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
INVESTMENTS can be popular or cheap, but rarely both. Emerging markets today are one of the exceptions, in the view of many portfolio managers.
 Professional investors around the world are heavily invested in the stock markets of developing countries. Forty-six percent of portfolio managers polled by Merrill Lynch in early June said they were overweight in emerging markets, meaning that they had a higher portion of their portfolios in these markets than would be suggested by a benchmark global index; 13 percent said they were underweight, while the remainder said their portfolio weighting was neutral. 
 The relatively large sums flowing into developing markets have helped them produce better returns than in larger ones. The global index of emerging markets compiled by Morgan Stanley Capital International returned 15.9 percent this year through June, compared with an 11.1 percent return for developed markets. 
Latching on to a hot investment sector can be dangerous, but advocates of emerging markets say that even after considering their strong performance this year, shares in these markets still look less expensive than those in developed countries.
"They are cheap on a number of measures relative to their own history, relative to developed markets and on an absolute basis," said David Gait, a senior analyst specializing in emerging markets in the Edinburgh office of First State Investments, a fund management firm. "It's not uncommon to find good-quality companies trading on single-digit price-earnings ratios, with double-digit growth rates and good and growing yields."
Many of those companies are traded on American markets. Others can be bought only on local markets through global brokerage houses. Alternative investment routes include traditional mutual funds -- Morningstar has 163 in its database that focus on emerging markets -- and closed-end funds, which often trade at a discount to their underlying asset values. Some funds concentrate on single countries, others on regions or on emerging markets worldwide. In addition, there are many exchange-traded index funds, some focused on a broad range of emerging markets, and others on smaller geographic slices.
Sam Mahtani, who runs an emerging markets fund for F&C Management in London, said that based on estimated 2003 earnings, developing markets over all have been trading at a price-earnings ratio of about 10, roughly half that of the American market. "That's a significant discount," he said, "but where it gets more interesting is when you look at returns on equity."
The typical publicly traded company in the developing world returns about 15 cents a year for every dollar of equity, he said. That is about the same as American companies, but by this measure, developing and developed markets have been heading in opposite directions. After the crisis of the late 1990's, when emerging markets in Asia and elsewhere experienced declining economies, currencies and share prices, their returns sank. In August 1998, Mr. Mahtani said, the returns on equity in the developing world were 7 percent, compared with more than 20 percent in the United States.
"The crisis forced policy responses from governments and the corporate sector because balance sheets were really bad," Mr. Mahtani said. "That has led to significant increases in profitability and shareholder returns." Many American companies, meanwhile, are beset by sluggish growth and excess capacity in many industries.
Mr. Mahtani acknowledged that shares in emerging markets often trade at lower price-earnings ratios than those in developed markets, but said that the present gap was excessive, especially considering the progress made since the slump of the 1990's.
"We feel such a huge discount is unwarranted given the significant change in corporate and government balance sheets since the Asia crisis," he said. "We do feel that emerging markets should trade at a discount to developed, but we feel a level of around 14 times earnings is more appropriate."
Growth in emerging markets has been aided by the decline of the dollar. "For many countries a weak dollar will help them to give a bit of internal stimulus to their economies, particularly to commodity exporters with U.S. dollar debt," he said.
Asia is a favored destination for fund managers. Mr. Mahtani prefers burgeoning consumer markets like India and South Korea. One of his fund's larger holdings is Reliance Industries, a diversified Indian holding company with extensive business in petrochemicals, a sector he likes. Another Indian company he owns is Ranbaxy Laboratories, a maker of generic drugs.
In Korea, which accounts for 21 percent of the fund's assets, the largest of any country, holdings include Kookmin Bank and SK Telecom. Both trade in the United States.
A European companyMr. Mahtani cited is Telekomunikacja Polska, the main Polish phone company. "We're finding a lot of value in fixed-line incumbents," he said.
Hugh Young, head of global equities at Aberdeen Asset Management, expressed interest in an eclectic range of stocks. Among his preferred Asian investments are Samsung Electronics in Korea, which makes computer chips and electrical appliances; PetroChina, the Chinese national oil company; GAIL, a natural-gas company in India; Hyundai Motor in Korea; and China Mobile (Hong Kong), the subsidiary of a government-owned Chinese phone company.
Mr. Young's selections in Latin America include Petroleo Brasileiro, the Brazilian national oil company also known as Petrobras; Telefonos de Mexico and Souza Cruz, the Brazilian subsidiary of British American Tobacco. The stocks he names are "all pretty cheap and leaders in their field." Many of his choices, including China Mobile, PetroChina and Petrobras, trade in the United States.
Mr. Gait looks for companies that have strong management and are industry leaders in the markets where they do business. He mentioned two of Mr. Young's holdings, Samsung Electronics and Petrobras.
Petrobras is "a leader in terms of offshore drilling and exploration," he said. "Its assets are clearly oil," he added. "It generates dollar revenues, so it's insulated from the ebbs and flows of the real and the local economy." (The real is Brazil's currency.) Mr. Gait called the stock a bargain, noting that it trades at half the valuation of similar oil companies in the developed world.
TWO Mexican companies Mr. Gait likes are Coca-Cola Femsa, a Mexican company that bottles Coke products across Latin America, and Grupo Televisa, the country's largest broadcaster. Televisa offers an opportunity to bet on economic recovery, he said, because media companies are more economically sensitive than others. Both stocks have American listings.
Two Indian companies Mr. Gait recommends, each with an American listing, are Infosys Technologies and HDFC Bank. Infosys supplies computer programming to companies in developed markets. Lower salaries in India allow it to compete effectively against Western rivals. While Infosys has been hurt by the downturn in technology spending, Mr. Gait described it as "a shining light in emerging markets, an extremely well-managed company that has done well building up its franchise."
He offered similar praise for HDFC, which he said had strong executives who were "conservative but innovative," a combination that has allowed them to compete effectively against India's inefficient state-run institutions. "When operating a bank in a country like India, the temptation must be to expand too quickly and grab every opportunity you can," he said, "but management has shown the awareness to grow the business at an appropriate pace."
Another selection from the region is John Keells, a Sri Lankan company with interests in beverages, ports and software. Conglomerates are out of favor elsewhere, "but in a place like Sri Lanka, with such a small economy, it probably makes sense to operate with that model," Mr. Gait said. Offering further justification for owning the stock, he declared: "They make the best ginger beer I've ever had."

HEADLINE: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS; 
Playoff or Cook-Off, It All Depends on the Batter

BYLINE:  By Kathryn Shattuck

 BODY:
JACQUES PEPIN, Wolfgang Puck, Emeril Lagasse, Paul Bocuse, Alain Ducasse: never mind that some of the biggest names in cooking are men's. In Eddie Ogden's household, baseball rules and the only place for a male interest in food is at the receiving end of a fork.
 So when Eddie, a star first baseman whose father happens to be the team coach, trades in his mitt and bat for a spatula and whisk, you can be sure there'll be plenty of heat in the kitchen. 
 "Eddie's Million Dollar Cook-Off," a Disney Channel Original Movie that has its premiere Friday at 8 p.m., follows the escapades of 14-year-old Eddie as he struggles to keep a lid on his passion for cooking in order to fulfill his father's and schoolmates' expectations. He experiments in the family kitchen under cover of darkness. He feigns disdain for the home economics class that he tricks his friends into taking with him. And when he signs up for the Scholastic Million Dollar Cook-Off and makes the finals -- which take place on the same day as the baseball playoffs -- Eddie must decide: does he follow his head or his heart? 
 "My parents are really supportive of me," said Taylor Ball, who plays Eddie, while talking about the acting career he began at 9 in his hometown, Granbury, Tex., before moving to California where he landed a spot on the CBS sitcom "Still Standing" and representation with the William Morris Agency. Off the set, Taylor rock-climbs, wails on the electric guitar and shoots home videos. On set, he spends his down time being tutored. "It's so much harder than normal school," he said. "First of all, I don't like school to begin with. And I'm a sophomore now, but I don't get to have a real school life with my friends and it is kind of discouraging."
 And even though his culinary skills are limited to cereal and French toast, Taylor does share with his character a passion for Food Network. "My mom and I sit there and watch it all the time," he said. "I watch 'Naked Chef,' Emeril and Bobby Flay."
 So Taylor found it "really, really cool" when he got to work with Mr. Flay, who portrays the million-dollar cook-off's enthusiastic host.
 "This was my first film and it's going to be my last," Mr. Flay said, chuckling at his self-consciousness about playing a scripted version of himself -- though as host of Food Network's "Hot Off the Grill With Bobby Flay" and "FoodNation," he's no stranger to the camera.
 Still, he could relate to Eddie's -- and Taylor's -- plight.
 "I was a pretty poor high school student, and I needed something other than book work," Mr. Flay said. At 17, he took a job in the kitchen at Joe Allen Restaurant in Manhattan, where his father was a partner. Mr. Allen was so impressed by Mr. Flay's natural talent that he paid his tuition to the prestigious French Culinary Institute in Manhattan.
 "It's never too early to start," said Mr. Flay, who recommended that youngsters interested in cooking begin as busboys in restaurants and then apprentice for a month in a kitchen before making a decision. "It's a great life, but it's so much harder than it looks." Kathryn Shattuck

GRAPHIC: Photos: The chef Bobby Flay, top left, plays a fictional version of himself in "Eddie's Million Dollar Cook-Off," starring Taylor Ball (above, left and below with Mark L. Taylor as his father). (Photographs from Disney Channel)

HEADLINE: The Road Ahead in Iraq -- and How to Navigate It 

BYLINE:  By L. Paul Bremer III; L. Paul Bremer III is the top American administrator in Iraq.

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq 

 BODY:
Americans can be proud of the role their fighting men and women played in freeing Iraq of Saddam Hussein and his cronies. The people of Iraq are now on the road to political and economic independence.
 The first official step in this political transition at the national level occurs today, with the convening of the Iraqi Governing Council. This is the latest sign of progress. For the first time in decades, Iraqis are truly free. More than 150 newspapers have been started since liberation. All major cities and 85 percent of towns now have a municipal council where Iraqis are increasingly taking responsibility for management of local matters like health care, water and electricity. 
 Iraqis are speaking out and demonstrating with a vigor borne of 35 years of imposed silence. This is not yet a full democracy, but freedom is on the march, from north to south. Sadly, this progress is despised by a narrow band of opponents. A small minority of bitter-enders -- members of the former regime's instruments of repression -- oppose such freedom. They are joined by foreign terrorists, extreme Islamists influenced by Iran and bands of criminals. These people do not pose a strategic threat to America or to a democratic Iraq. They enjoy no support since their only vision is to reimpose the dictatorship hated by Iraqis. Our military will hunt them down and, as President Bush said, "They will face ruin, just as surely as the regime they once served."
These shadowy figures are killing brave Iraqis working with us, attacking soldiers and civilians, and trying to sabotage the fragile infrastructure. The attacks have drawn concern worldwide. My coalition colleagues and Iraqi friends have noticed that the attacks are often aimed at successes in the renewal of this nation. A week ago, an American soldier was mixing with students at Baghdad University, which reopened on May 17. Their presence was testimony to the educational progress that is blossoming here (public schools have also reopened). But our enemies fear enlightenment, so one of them killed the soldier. 
The day before, 250 Iraqi police recruits graduated, the latest success in re-staffing law enforcement. Tens of thousands of Iraqi policemen are now on duty. But the enemies of freedom correctly felt threatened by the cooperation and professionalism the day represented, so they set off a bomb that killed seven new officers. Before the war, women had to travel miles for propane. Now, local councils are establishing distribution centers that make the gas readily available to households. On June 18, one American soldier was killed while guarding a center. The June 24th explosion at an oil refinery in Barwanah is another example of political sabotage on Iraq's energy supply. 
With these attacks on Iraq's new successes, citizens of coalition nations ask how long we will remain in Iraq -- and some Iraqis may doubt our ability to improve their lives. As President Bush has made clear, we are committed to establishing the conditions for security, prosperity and democracy. America has no designs on Iraq and its wealth. We will finish our job here and stay not one day longer than necessary.
We have a plan to support the establishment of this government of, by and for Iraqis. After months of consultations with Iraqis, we have taken the first step in establishing an interim administration. Today, the Governing Council of Iraq will meet. It represents all the strands from Iraq's complicated social structure -- Shiites, Sunnis, Arabs, Kurds, men and women, Christians and Turkmens. The council will immediately exercise real political power, appointing interim ministers and working with the coalition on policy and budgets.
At the same time, the council will establish procedures to write Iraq's new constitution. Once it is ratified by the people, elections can be held and a sovereign Iraqi government will come into being. So the question of how long the coalition will stay in Iraq depends in part on how quickly the Iraqi people can write and approve a constitution. 
The coalition recognizes the urgency of marrying economic well-being to political freedom. For 35 years, the country's assets were misappropriated or stolen. We are pouring resources into re-establishing basic services and creating jobs. Our economic reform plan will entail a major shift of capital from the value-destroying state sector to private firms. We are also creating a social safety net for any resulting disruptions. And we believe that a method should be found to assure that every citizen benefits from Iraq's oil wealth. One possibility would be to pay social benefits from a trust financed by oil revenues. Another could be to pay an annual cash dividend directly to each citizen from that trust. 
In all this, the coalition is working closely with Iraqis who will eventually be responsible for their country's well-being. For our three priorities -- security, politics and the economy -- the strategy provides for the successful transition to a stable and reformed Iraq. This does not mean that the road ahead is without danger. The combination of a broken infrastructure and acts of sabotage could mean a rough summer. We will suffer casualties, as the bitter-enders resort to violence. We are also braced for an increase in terrorism by non-Iraqis, but no one should doubt our determination to use our power in the face of violent acts.
Once our work is over, the reward will be great: a free, democratic and independent Iraq that stands not as a threat to its neighbors or the world, but as a beacon of freedom and justice.

HEADLINE: Near End of His Africa Trip, Bush Focuses on Liberia 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: ABUJA, Nigeria, July 12 

 BODY:
President Bush held talks today with Nigeria's leader on how to bring peace and stability to Liberia as the United States moved toward a decision about whether to send peacekeeping troops there.
 Wrapping up his swing through Africa, the president met with President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, who updated Mr. Bush on the Nigerian effort to persuade President Charles Taylor of Liberia to step down. Mr. Obasanjo has played a leading role in an American-backed plan to pressure Mr. Taylor to quit and to pave the way for a cease-fire in a civil war that has ravaged Liberia and destabilized its neighbors. 
 A senior American official said Mr. Obasanjo had told Mr. Bush that Mr. Taylor was negotiating the terms of the proposal for him to come to Nigeria. The official said Mr. Taylor's primary concern was bringing his family with him.
The official said Mr. Bush and Mr. Obasanjo did not discuss whether Mr. Taylor would receive immunity from the war crimes charges lodged against him by a United Nations-backed court in neighboring Sierra Leone. Nigeria does not have an extradition law that would force Mr. Taylor to go to Sierra Leone to face the charges, which stem from accusations about his part in brutal factional fighting in Sierra Leone.
Mr. Bush has repeatedly called for Mr. Taylor to step down, and has said the United States will play a role in peacekeeping efforts being led by a group of West African nations. He has left open the possibility that the United States would send troops to Liberia, but he has not yet made a decision.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said this week that Mr. Bush might make a decision within a few days. Mr. Bush is to discuss Liberia at a meeting on Monday in Washington with the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan. He is also scheduled to receive reports from two military teams sent to the region to assess what role the United States should play.
Asked by a reporter today if he would make a decision in the coming week, Mr. Bush replied, "I'm not sure yet when."
Mr. Bush also used his stop in Nigeria, the fifth and final nation on his first tour of Africa as president, to promote his proposal to spend $15 billion over the next five years to help some of the world's poorest countries combat AIDS.
As he has on nearly every day of the trip, Mr. Bush, who has made holding down federal spending on nearly all nonmilitary programs a cornerstone of his agenda, pledged not to let Congress reduce the budget for his AIDS plan.
"The House of Representatives and the United States Senate must fully fund this initiative, for the good of the people on this continent of Africa," Mr. Bush said in a speech.
With a group of AIDS officials at a hospital here, he was more direct. "We have talked and now it's time to write the check," Mr. Bush said "We're in the process of debating the appropriation process. I'm confident this trip will provide the impetus to appropriate the funds."
But there has been considerable confusion in Congress and among groups advocating more money for AIDS programs about what Mr. Bush considers full financing for the program. Mr. Bush originally requested $2 billion for the coming year, with the idea that financing would increase in future years so that $15 billion would be spent over five years. But legislation that Mr. Bush signed this spring called for $3 billion for next year, a level that advocacy groups said the White House needed to honor.
This week a House subcommittee moved to appropriate $2 billion for the coming year. A senior White House official said Mr. Bush was happy with that figure, although he still wanted to remove some restrictions in the legislation on how the money could be used.
"In the first year it's going to take less money to get the job done than in the out years," the official said.
Mr. Bush's visit underscored Nigeria's progress in developing a democratic government and reducing its AIDS rate, and -- perhaps most of all -- highlighted its growing importance as a source of oil. Its status as one of the world's fastest-growing oil-and-gas producers guarantees it regular attention from Washington.
In the past, much of Nigeria's oil wealth has been siphoned off by corrupt government and private-sector officials. But Mr. Obasanjo has tried to crack down on corruption, a point he emphasized to Mr. Bush today.
An administration official said Mr. Bush suggested to Mr. Obasanjo that Nigeria use its energy wealth to plan for a future in which it would be a bigger part of the world economy. Mr. Bush, the official said, told Mr. Obasanjo that Africa's economic future was not in textiles, a major industry here and in many other African countries, because it faced increased competition from other low-cost producers like China.
Instead, Mr. Bush said, Nigeria should develop a high-tech sector.
About two-thirds of Nigerians live below the poverty line.
